TEXT:
Durante 11 minutos el 2 de noviembre, realmente hubo paz en la Tierra.

Luego, la cuenta de Twitter del presidente Donald Trump fue reactivada.

Twitter culp√≥ a un "empleado deshonesto" que durante su √∫ltimo d√≠a en el trabajo elimin√≥ la cuenta de The Donald.

Trump jura que Twitter fue clave para que llegara a la Casa Blanca

Ahora, el hombre responsable que hizo temporalmente imposible que Trump tuitera, revel√≥ su identidad y explic√≥ sus acciones en una entrevista exclusiva con TechCrunch.

Su nombre es Bahtiyar Duysak, es un ciudadano alem√°n con ra√≠ces turcas que trabaj√≥ en soporte al cliente para la divisi√≥n de Confianza y Seguridad de Twitter mientras estaba en Estados Unidos con una visa de trabajo y estudio. Parte de su responsabilidad era lidiar con alertas que informaban de mal comportamiento, tuits ofensivos o ilegales y otras formas de acoso.

Durante su √∫ltimo turno, alguien report√≥ la cuenta de Trump y, sin pensarlo, Duysak puso manos a la obra y la desactiv√≥. Varias horas m√°s tarde, se dio cuenta de que hab√≠a cometido un "error", especialmente despu√©s de ver varias noticias al respecto.

Donald Trump vale 2 mil millones de d√≥lares en Twitter: analista

Duysak dijo que nunca pens√≥ que la cuenta de Trump en realidad ser√≠a desactivada, principalmente debido a una pol√≠tica de Twitter que protege los tuits que se consideran de inter√©s period√≠stico, incluso si pudieran violar sus t√©rminos de servicio.

Duysak, que est√° de vuelta en Alemania, trat√≥ de permanecer oculto por un tiempo, pero decidi√≥ salir de las sombras.

"Quiero tener una vida ordinaria. No quiero huir de los medios ", dijo a TechCrunch. "No hice ning√∫n crimen ni nada malo, pero me siento como Pablo Escobar, y poco a poco se est√° volviendo realmente molesto".

Duysak dijo que no est√° interesado en una carrera en tecnolog√≠a y es m√°s probable que considere un trabajo en finanzas.

Agrega: "Pero amo Twitter y amo a Estados Unidos".

Este texto se public√≥ originalmente en HuffPost.
TITLE: Conozcan al hombre que borr√≥ temporalmente la cuenta de Trump en Twitter

SUMMARY:
Viste lo que soy: una chica asustada que se esfuerza por no dejar que nadie vea el miedo en sus ojos.
Viste lo que soy: una chica asustada que se esfuerza por no dejar que nadie vea el miedo en sus ojos.
Met√≠ en la maleta todos los que ten√≠a y dinero para comprarme otro porque cre√≠a que no ten√≠a ninguno apropiado que me lo tapara todo.
Esa ma√±ana, en el √∫ltimo momento, decid√≠ ponerme un bikini, como si de mi tripa no sobresaliera nada.
Llevaba poco tiempo en la playa cuando apareciste y ya me sent√≠a inc√≥moda y pensaba que todo el mundo me estaba mirando.
TEXT:
Este post fue publicado originalmente en la web de The Mighty.

Escrito por Sara Gebert

No s√© si te cost√≥ mucho acercarte a m√≠ en la playa, pero s√© que a m√≠ me cuesta mucho hablar con desconocidos. Pero te me acercaste tan campante, con tal seguridad que nadie esperar√≠a que ninguna de las dos tuviera problemas de autoestima, aunque parezca que siempre llevo conmigo un aura de inseguridad. Viste lo que soy: una chica asustada que se esfuerza por no dejar que nadie vea el miedo en sus ojos.

No s√© si te acercaste a m√≠ por eso o no, pero quiero darte las gracias. Vivir con una enfermedad cr√≥nica no es f√°cil, y es a√∫n m√°s duro cuando es una enfermedad que cambia el aspecto, como es mi caso. Cuando voy completamente vestida, nadie se da cuenta de que no soy una persona "t√≠pica", pero cuando estoy en la playa es otra historia.

Viste lo que soy: una chica asustada que se esfuerza por no dejar que nadie vea el miedo en sus ojos.

En la playa todo el mundo est√° expuesto, pero yo encima llevo cosas colgando. Llevo una bolsa de ileostom√≠a, un tubo G y un tubo J, no es algo que se vea todos los d√≠as. Yo estoy acostumbrada; para m√≠, son cosas normales.

Pero, para el resto del mundo, parezco salida de una pel√≠cula de ciencia ficci√≥n. En cambio, t√∫ me miraste como si fuera una persona. No te quedaste observando mi bolsa y mis tubos, me miraste a los ojos y me diste las gracias.

No estoy segura de si te diste cuenta, pero me qued√© pasmada. Otras veces se me ha acercado gente a decirme "qu√© asco" o a preguntarme si me iba a meter a la piscina as√≠. Y, cuando te me acercaste, estaba preparada para lo peor. Todav√≠a no me creo lo que sucedi√≥.

Me diste las gracias por llevar bikini, me dijiste que estaba estupenda y me contaste que t√∫ tambi√©n hab√≠as llevado una bolsa de ileostom√≠a y que ya no ten√≠as intestino grueso. Me dijiste que yo era una inspiraci√≥n. Significa mucho para m√≠.

Cuando estaba haciendo la maleta para irme de viaje, me pas√© horas agonizando y pensando qu√© trajes de ba√±o llevarme. Met√≠ en la maleta todos los que ten√≠a y dinero para comprarme otro porque cre√≠a que no ten√≠a ninguno apropiado que me lo tapara todo.

Esa ma√±ana, en el √∫ltimo momento, decid√≠ ponerme un bikini, como si de mi tripa no sobresaliera nada. Estaba muy nerviosa. Hay muchas adolescentes que no se sienten c√≥modas con su cuerpo, y desde que me hicieron la ostom√≠a mi incomodidad se multiplic√≥ por cien. Llevaba poco tiempo en la playa cuando apareciste y ya me sent√≠a inc√≥moda y pensaba que todo el mundo me estaba mirando.

Pero despu√©s de hablar contigo mis preocupaciones desaparecieron. En ese momento, me di cuenta de que el aspecto no importaba y de que mi √∫nico problema iba a ser que me hab√≠a llevado m√°s trajes de ba√±o de los que iba a poder ponerme.

Gracias por devolverme la fe en la humanidad.

As√≠ que te doy las gracias. Gracias por devolverme la fe en la humanidad. Gracias por hacer que me sintiera c√≥moda siendo como soy. Y, por √∫ltimo, gracias por darme la seguridad necesaria para disfrutar de mis vacaciones al m√°ximo.

Este post fue publicado anteriormente en la edici√≥n estadounidense del 'HuffPost' y ha sido traducido del ingl√©s por Lara Eleno Romero para El HuffPost.

*Este contenido representa la opini√≥n del autor y no necesariamente la de HuffPost M√©xico.
TITLE: A la mujer que me dijo que estaba guap√≠sima en bikini

SUMMARY:
My son got a toy shop voucher last Christmas -- a great gift for him, a diplomatic mission for me.
There's something condemning about our culture when a child can leave a toy shop unhappy.
My son and I separated shortly after we first walked into the toy shop.
I don't know what we bought for my son in the toy shop that day.
I don't know what we bought for my son in the toy shop that day.
TEXT:
"I stayed behind to look at toys that don't get their own commercials."

My son got a toy shop voucher last Christmas -- a great gift for him, a diplomatic mission for me. He was always going to want something bigger and better than the voucher could afford. There's something condemning about our culture when a child can leave a toy shop unhappy.

As it turned out, though, he was fine. It was me who wandered into a weird experience; the toys sparking another in a series of middle-age crises.

My son and I separated shortly after we first walked into the toy shop. I wanted to show him the model planes and boats I used to build when I was a kid. He had no interest in those and ran off to find the latest Ninjago and Nexo Knights box sets -- Lego subcultures I didn't fully understand.

What came first, anyway, the toy or the TV show? Or were they released together, a marketing blitzkrieg on eight to 10-year-old boys.

I stayed behind to look at toys that don't get their own commercials. Model rocket kits that you build and paint yourself, and fly with combustible powder engine cartridges that look like little sticks of dynamite.

I don't know what we bought for my son in the toy shop that day. It doesn't really matter. Not yet.

I loved those rockets. Every launch was a neighborhood event, complete with countdown. Sometimes they fizzled on the launch pad. Sometimes they blasted off to what seemed like the edge of earth's atmosphere, at least to my nine-year-old imagination. I lost more than one of those rockets to suburban rooftops when their parachutes failed to open. Preparing for the descent was not on my radar.

This toy shop was well stocked. I picked up boxes of model airplanes; a 'Spitfire', a 'Messerschmitt', complete with decals, rotating propellers and even tiny pilots in accurate uniform. I loved all the detail and remembered how my cheap, glossy paints never gave my own model planes the professional finish I was after. I guess I'd left a few toy stores disappointed, too.

I heard a song through the toy shop's weak, tinny speakers and worked hard to ignore the tune. It was Kajagoogoo's 'Too Shy', a song that reminded me of an improbably, intimidatingly beautiful girl who once broke my heart. I didn't want that grown up memory polluting my pure enjoyment of these toys.

I wanted to stay with the boxes of model railway cars and the scenery: the hollowed out plastic mountain tunnel sprayed with synthetic moss, the boxes of little cloud sheep, the half-dozen miniature sunbathers waiting to be released from their hermetically sealed plastic dome.

It was in that toy shop that I finally understood the phenomenon of middle-aged dedication to model railways. It was all built on nostalgia; a yearning to manifest a platonic ideal of the world in miniature that had never -- could never -- exist in a world populated by real people who don't emerge from a plastic case, designed, knees bent, with no other purpose than to sit on a park bench, or endlessly punch tickets on a railway platform.

Models are about making time stand still.

I don't know what we bought for my son in the toy shop that day. It doesn't really matter. Not yet.
TITLE: I Took My Son To A Toy Shop And Found They Stock Mid-Life Crises

Samir Hussein via Getty ImagesThis is a variation on Harry's sometimes-confusing signature hand pose.
When he tucked his hand into his jacket at an event with first lady Melania Trump in September, some speculated that he was making the sign of the devil.
It's a lot more innocuous than that, though: According to Brown, putting one‚Äôs hand on one‚Äôs stomach is an act of self-comfort.
"Here again we see Harry guarding his solar plexus -- the part of your stomach, below your ribs, where it can be painful if you are hit hard," she said.
It's something we need to get used to seeing as he's in the news more."
TEXT:
Samir Hussein via Getty Images

This is a variation on Harry's sometimes-confusing signature hand pose. When he tucked his hand into his jacket at an event with first lady Melania Trump in September, some speculated that he was making the sign of the devil. It's a lot more innocuous than that, though: According to Brown, putting one‚Äôs hand on one‚Äôs stomach is an act of self-comfort."Here again we see Harry guarding his solar plexus -- the part of your stomach, below your ribs, where it can be painful if you are hit hard," she said. "It's his habit and a way to guard against the media and crowds. It's something we need to get used to seeing as he's in the news more."
TITLE: Body Language Experts Decode Prince Harry And Meghan Markle's First Official Outing

SUMMARY:
Melissa Schuman, an original member of the pop group Dream, has accused Nick Carter of the Backstreet Boys of raping her in 2002.
In a statement to HuffPost, Carter denied Schuman‚Äôs accusations and said he was ‚Äúalways respectful and supportive‚Äù of her during the time they worked together.
He didn‚Äôt respond and continued to kiss me,‚Äù Schuman wrote.
He didn‚Äôt care.‚ÄùRay Stubblebine / Reuters Schuman (far right) with other members of the music group Dream in New York in 2001.
Schuman wrote that she was a virgin at the time and held herself ‚Äúto religious conservative christian values,‚Äù which she was ‚Äúvocal about‚Äù during her stardom.
TEXT:
Melissa Schuman, an original member of the pop group Dream, has accused Nick Carter of the Backstreet Boys of raping her in 2002.

In an essay she published Tuesday night on her personal website, Schuman said Carter raped her while she and a friend were hanging out at his Santa Monica apartment. According to Schuman, she was 18 at the time, Carter was 22.

In a statement to HuffPost, Carter denied Schuman‚Äôs accusations and said he was ‚Äúalways respectful and supportive‚Äù of her during the time they worked together.

‚ÄúI am shocked and saddened by Ms. Schuman‚Äôs accusations. Melissa never expressed to me while we were together or at any time since that anything we did was not consensual,‚Äù the statement reads. ‚ÄúWe went on to record a song and perform together, and I was always respectful and supportive of Melissa, both personally and professionally. This is the first that I am hearing about these accusations, nearly two decades later. It is contrary to my nature and everything I hold dear to intentionally cause someone discomfort or harm.‚Äù

Schuman in her essay said that a small group of friends were having drinks at Carter‚Äôs apartment when he asked if she wanted to go to his office to hear some new music. While listening, the two began kissing and Carter led her into the bathroom.

‚ÄúI asked him what we were doing in there. He didn‚Äôt respond and continued to kiss me,‚Äù Schuman wrote. ‚ÄúHe then pick (sic) me up, put me on the bathroom counter and started to unbutton my pants. I told him I didn‚Äôt want to go any further. He didn‚Äôt listen. He didn‚Äôt care.‚Äù

Ray Stubblebine / Reuters Schuman (far right) with other members of the music group Dream in New York in 2001.

Schuman wrote that she was a virgin at the time and held herself ‚Äúto religious conservative christian values,‚Äù which she was ‚Äúvocal about‚Äù during her stardom.

She said that Carter forced oral sex on her and later pressured her to perform oral sex on him.

‚ÄúI felt scared and trapped. He was visually and clearly growing very angry and impatient with me,‚Äù she wrote. ‚ÄúIt was evident to me, that I couldn‚Äôt leave. He was stronger and much bigger than me, and there was no way I would be able to open that door or have anyone help me.‚Äù

According to Schuman, Carter took her into a bedroom where he raped her despite her protests.

‚ÄúHe threw me on the bed and climbed on top of me,‚Äù she wrote. ‚ÄúHe was relentless, refusing to take my no‚Äôs for an answer. He was heavy, too heavy to get out from under him. Then I felt it, he put something inside of me. I asked him what it was and he whispered in my ear ... ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs all me baby.‚Äô It was done.‚Äù

Schuman said she considered pressing charges at the time, but decided against doing so for several reasons. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt have the money, the clout or access to an attorney who was powerful enough to stand up against my abuser‚Äôs legal counsel,‚Äù she wrote. ‚ÄúI was told I would likely be buried in humiliation, accused of being fame hungry, and it would ultimately hurt me professionally as well as publicly.‚Äù

She said she‚Äôs coming forward now in the wake of the #MeToo movement to show other victims of sexual assault they‚Äôre not alone.

‚ÄúI feel I have an obligation now to come forward with the hope and intention to inspire and encourage other victims to tell their story,‚Äù she wrote. ‚ÄúWe are stronger in numbers. If you are reading this and you have been assaulted, know you don‚Äôt have to be silent and you are not alone. I know it‚Äôs scary. I‚Äôm scared.‚Äù

The statute of limitations in California for rape cases had been 10 years, unless new DNA evidence emerged. Last year, the state enacted a law doing away ‚Äï as of 2017 ‚Äï with the time limit for prosecuting alleged rapes.

Hayley Miller contributed reporting.
TITLE: Backstreet Boys' Nick Carter Accused Of Raping A Member Of Pop Group Dream In 2002

SUMMARY:
After getting off to a slow start, the ‚ÄòStrictly‚Äô quarter-final stepped up a gear when last week‚Äôs leaderboard-topper Joe McFadden took to the floor.
His partner Katya Jones took a risk, with an unconventional song choice and choreography, but their efforts paid off.
Conversely, while Davood Ghadami and Mollie King‚Äôs routines looked like surefire crowd-pleasers on paper - with well-known tunes and familiar dances - the celebs failed to impress the panel.
The first wow moment of the episode came courtesy of the phenomenal Debbie McGee, who battled through back problems to deliver an emotionally-charged American Smooth.
And providing a lesson in how to bounce back in style, Alexandra Burke reminded everyone why she‚Äôs still a favourite to win the competition, barely pausing for breath between cartwheels, lifts and footwork-heavy bars.
TEXT:
After getting off to a slow start, the ‚ÄòStrictly‚Äô quarter-final stepped up a gear when last week‚Äôs leaderboard-topper Joe McFadden took to the floor. His partner Katya Jones took a risk, with an unconventional song choice and choreography, but their efforts paid off.

Conversely, while Davood Ghadami and Mollie King‚Äôs routines looked like surefire crowd-pleasers on paper - with well-known tunes and familiar dances - the celebs failed to impress the panel.

The first wow moment of the episode came courtesy of the phenomenal Debbie McGee, who battled through back problems to deliver an emotionally-charged American Smooth.

And providing a lesson in how to bounce back in style, Alexandra Burke reminded everyone why she‚Äôs still a favourite to win the competition, barely pausing for breath between cartwheels, lifts and footwork-heavy bars.

Viewers quickly took to social media to applaud the women‚Äôs work, with several calling it the anthem we need right now.

TEXT:
The women of ‚ÄúSaturday Night Live‚Äù hit back at the widespread news of sexual harassment allegations with a ‚ÄúWelcome to Hell‚Äù skit to remind us that none of these allegations ‚Äï as shocking as they may be ‚Äï is actually anything new.

‚ÄúHey there, boys, we know the last couple months have been insane,‚Äù Cecily Strong says while referring to the reports of rape, harassment and other misconduct against high-profile men since the Harvey Weinstein scandal broke.

‚ÄúAll of these big, cool, powerful guys are turning out to be, what‚Äôs the word, habitual predators,‚Äù Aidy Bryant adds. ‚ÄúAnd it‚Äôs like, dang, is this the world now?‚Äù

That‚Äôs when Strong breaks the news to anyone still living under a rock: ‚ÄúThis been the damn world.‚Äù

"Saturday Night Live"/NBC The women of "SNL" tackle sexual harassment in a "Welcome to Hell" music video.

Despite the whimsical Katy Perry look, with floating cherries, clouds and giant lollipops, the video didn‚Äôt sugarcoat the growing list of issues women face ‚Äï and have faced for centuries.

Flashbacks included scenes of women‚Äôs suffrage, witch burning and a male-dominated workplace reminiscent of the TV show ‚ÄúMad Men.‚Äù

Leslie Jones also stepped in to remind everyone that ‚Äúit‚Äôs like a million times worse for a woman of color.‚Äù

‚ÄúNow ‚ÄòHouse of Cards‚Äô is ruined, and that really sucks. Well here‚Äôs a list of stuff that‚Äôs ruined for us,‚Äù actress Saoirse Ronan says before they tick through a list that includes parking, walking, Uber, ponytails, bathrobes, nighttime, drinking, hotels and vans.

Viewers quickly took to social media to applaud the women‚Äôs work, with several calling it the anthem we need right now.

I AM GOING TO PLAY WELCOME TO HELL FOR EVERY GUY I MEET THAT COMPLAINS ABOUT HOW "FEMINAZIS" ARE RUINING EVERYTHING #SNL ‚Äî crayola‚Ñ¢ (@fakedannydevito) December 3, 2017

OMG ‚ÄúWelcome to Hell‚Äù

I needed this!!

Thank God for #SNL ‚Äî Peg Phillips üè≥Ô∏è‚Äçüåà (@PegPhillipsCPA) December 3, 2017

#SNL's "Welcome to Hell" music video is the anthem of 2017. pic.twitter.com/yRO79S8Z3g ‚Äî Devan Coggan (@devancoggan) December 3, 2017

omg "Welcome to Hell" is the anthem we all need right now. #SNL ‚Äî Tatum Tollner (@TatumTollner) December 3, 2017

‚ÄúWelcome to Hell‚Äù is the women‚Äôs anthem we need right now.



(And every year since the beginning of time.) pic.twitter.com/MYxkJ1iM8Y ‚Äî MelanieEnglishMedina (@BrooklynMelanie) December 3, 2017

"You do realize it‚Äôs 10x worse for a woman of color right?" Welcome to hell #snl pic.twitter.com/peIA5FeU58 ‚Äî Courtney (@KcirdnekC) December 3, 2017

I was all about this "Welcome to Hell" video, and then Leslie Jones showed up to say it's literally even worse if you're a WOC and it got even better. #SNL ‚Äî CRT (@StoryofEverest) December 3, 2017
TITLE: 'SNL's' 'Welcome To Hell' Skit On Sexual Harassment Is The Anthem We Need

SUMMARY:
No biscuit quite says 'Christmas' like gingerbread cookies -- the fragrance of cinnamon and nutmeg filling the house, the sweet, caramely flavour, the cute little shapes.
Gingerbread cookies are a cinch to make.
And if you want to spice them up even more, there's a second recipe for chocolate gingerbread cookies.
Plus, as these recipes use wholesome ingredients like spelt flour, buckwheat flour and unrefined sugar, these treats are somewhat healthier than your regular gingerbread cookies.
Chocolate gingerbread menAn indulgent twist on a classic favourite, these gingerbread men help spread the Christmas cheer.
TEXT:
No biscuit quite says 'Christmas' like gingerbread cookies -- the fragrance of cinnamon and nutmeg filling the house, the sweet, caramely flavour, the cute little shapes. The best part? Gingerbread cookies are a cinch to make.

If you can't get enough of Christmas (even if it's a month away) or are thinking about making homemade gifts this Christmas, try this recipe for gingerbread men by Teresa Cutter, aka The Healthy Chef. And if you want to spice them up even more, there's a second recipe for chocolate gingerbread cookies.

Plus, as these recipes use wholesome ingredients like spelt flour, buckwheat flour and unrefined sugar, these treats are somewhat healthier than your regular gingerbread cookies.

Gingerbread men

These are the perfect addition to your Christmas table or bundled together as a delicious gift. What I love about these cookies is that they taste like shortbread with a delicate hint of vanilla and spice.

Makes 30 cookies, depending on the size of your cutter.

INGREDIENTS

250g (1 cup) butter, softened

80g (¬Ω cup) rapadura or coconut sugar

1 tablespoon raw honey

Pinch sea salt

1 teaspoon vanilla extract

1 organic egg

360g (3 cups) wholemeal spelt flour

1 teaspoon baking powder

1 teaspoon ground cinnamon

1 teaspoon ginger

100g good quality white chocolate for decoration (optional)

METHOD

Cream the butter, rapadura, honey, sea salt and vanilla with a whisk or the paddle attachment of your mixer. Scrape the sides of your bowl and add the egg. Mix ingredients until combined. Combine the spelt flour, baking powder, cinnamon and ginger in a separate bowl. Add dry ingredients with the wet ingredients and mix until combined. Scrape the dough onto a piece of baking paper and flatten slightly. Wrap up the dough with another piece of baking paper and place into the fridge to rest for at least two hours. Preheat oven to 160¬∞C (320¬∞F) fan-forced. Remove dough from the fridge and roll between two sheets of baking paper until the dough is ¬Ω cm thick. Cut the cookies into shapes (you can use gingerbread cookie cutters, squares, circles or any other shape you would love your cookie to be). Place cookies onto a lined baking tray. Bake for 20‚Äì30 minutes or until cookies are just golden. Remove cookies from the oven and cool completely. Decorate the cookies with white chocolate, if you desire, or serve on their own.

Notes: to decorate your cookies, melt white chocolate in a small bowl over a small pot of simmering water. When the chocolate is completely melted, remove from the heat and pour into a small piping bag made from baking paper. Decorate your cookies and enjoy.

Chocolate gingerbread men

An indulgent twist on a classic favourite, these gingerbread men help spread the Christmas cheer. The antioxidants from the cacao helps to naturally boost the feel-good chemicals in the body.

Makes 30 cookies, depending on the size of your cutter.

INGREDIENTS

240g (1 cup) butter

80g (¬Ω cup) rapadura, coconut sugar or unrefined raw sugar

1 teaspoon vanilla extract

Pinch sea salt

240g (2 cups) buckwheat flour

60g (¬Ω cup) cacao powder

¬Ω teaspoon baking powder

1 teaspoon ground cinnamon

100g good quality white chocolate for decoration (optional)

METHOD

Combine butter, rapadura, vanilla and sea salt into the mixing bowl of a stand mixer fitted with the paddle attachment. Beat well for 5-8 minutes until light and creamy. Combine buckwheat flour, cacao, baking powder and cinnamon in a separate bowl. Add dry ingredients into the creamed butter and mix through lightly until combined. Scrape the dough onto a piece of baking paper and flatten slightly. Wrap up the dough with another piece of baking paper and place into the fridge to rest for at least four hours. Preheat your oven to 160¬∞C (320¬∞F) fan-forced. Remove the dough from the fridge and roll between two sheets of baking paper until the dough is ¬Ω cm thick. Cut the cookies into your desired shapes and place them onto a lined baking tray. Bake for 20‚Äì30 minutes or until cookies are cooked through. Remove cookies from the oven and cool completely. Decorate the cookies with melted white chocolate, if you desire, or serve on their own.

Notes: add 100g dark chocolate pieces to make luscious choc chip gingerbread cookies.
TITLE: How To Make Easy Gingerbread Men

SUMMARY:
In other words, he had bleeding in his brain caused by two ruptured cerebral aneurysms.
According to the Australian Brain Foundation, aneurysms are present in approximately two percent of adults, and more than 10 percent of those people will experience more than one rupture.
In 40 percent of cases paramedics report the patient has regained consciousness on the way to the hospital,‚Äù Nichols said.
While Rixon and Rushton can be considered two of the ‚Äúlucky‚Äù ones they don‚Äôt always see it that way.
And for more information on brain aneurysms visit The Brain Foundation Australia.
TEXT:
Brain aneurysm. 3D computed tomography (CT) angiogram coupled with a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan of the brain of a 38-year-old, showing a large aneurysm (bright, lower centre) of the right internal carotid artery. An aneurysm is the ballooning of an artery due to weakening of the artery wall.

Caleb Rixon was in the middle of a pump class when he felt by a sharp pain in his skull. He was training for the Australian tour of Chicago, the musical he‚Äôd just been cast in. The pain was so strong, that Rixon assumed his eyeball had been pushed from its socket. He stopped class, moved to a mirror and when he was able to confirm his eyeball was still in place, he decided to grab a drink.

‚ÄúIt felt like my eye had shattered or fallen out of my skull,‚Äù Rixon told The Huffington Post Australia.

‚ÄúIt was like I‚Äôd been struck by lightning. It‚Äôs like a thunderbolt went into me and through my eye and I was left with a body that was still trying to deal with being fried.‚Äù

Rixon, who was just 24 years old at the time, would later learn this ‚Äúthunderbolt‚Äù was in fact a Grade 5 Subarachnoid Hemorrhage due to a Dural Arteriovenous Malformation. In other words, he had bleeding in his brain caused by two ruptured cerebral aneurysms.

According to the Australian Brain Foundation, aneurysms are present in approximately two percent of adults, and more than 10 percent of those people will experience more than one rupture.

For 25 minutes after the initial burst of pain, Rixon remained conscious. He remembers losing the ability to swallow and speak. He also remembers feeling his body fly out of control.

‚ÄúIt was like my body was separating itself from my mind and my limbs were just sort of flying and people were holding me,‚Äù he said.

Rixon was taken to hospital. His parents were called and told to come immediately because doctors didn‚Äôt think he would make it through the night.

‚ÄúI was on life support and unconscious. Without surgery I was definitely going to die, but with the surgery I only had a one in three chance of survival,‚Äù he said.

When he woke from surgery, Rixon was unable to stand, walk, swallow, speak or see on his own.

Linda Nichols, Coordinator of Neuroscience Nursing at University of Tasmania, says the chances of a rupture in someone as young as Rixon are quite rare. ‚ÄúEighty percent of cases usually occur between the ages of 40 and 65,‚Äù Nichols said. For this reason, and despite all of his symptoms, Rixon assumed he was fine up until the moment he was rushed to emergency. He just felt ‚Äútired and dehydrated,‚Äù as he lay prone on the floor unable to move.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs difficult because 25 percent actually walk back out of the hospital because their condition improves. In 40 percent of cases paramedics report the patient has regained consciousness on the way to the hospital,‚Äù Nichols said.

‚ÄúPeople will often say they had a sudden onset headache, but what‚Äôs sudden?‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you have an instantaneous, incapacitating headache and it reached its maximum intensity in less than a minute, you should seek professional help immediately.‚Äù

Many patients -- 10 - 15 percent -- die from initial bleeding and 40 percent die from later complications.

‚ÄúThe risk of a second bleed increases in the first 24 hours,‚Äù Nichols said. ‚ÄúAnything can trigger a re-rupture.‚Äù

For Jodie Rushton, 49, two ‚Äúpimple-sized‚Äù aneurysm ruptures left her fighting for her life in intensive care a fortnight ago. ‚ÄúIt was in the afternoon and she just got home from work,‚Äù her daughter Tiffany Rushton told HuffPost Australia. ‚ÄúShe couldn‚Äôt stand, she was trying to use the bench and she couldn‚Äôt move her legs. The weird thing was she was talking saying she felt sick and she was vomiting.

‚ÄúShe had a seizure and my brother ran out the front to get help. Luckily, the lady who lives across the street, Megan, who we‚Äôd never spoken to before works in a hospital so she was able to help and knew what to do.‚Äù

Once the ambulance arrived, Rushton had another seizure and the paramedics put her into an induced coma. Up until that point she was refusing to go to hospital, insisting it was just a headache.

‚ÄúMum was in ICU for 12 days in total and is now in a brain ward. They woke her up just over a week ago and we were petrified she wouldn‚Äôt be able to talk or would have memory loss. The left side of her body wasn‚Äôt moving at one stage but now it is and every day she‚Äôs getting stronger,‚Äù Rushton said.

‚ÄúShe was able to speak, too. It was hard to understand at first, like she was speaking another language, but every day she‚Äôs been better and she can eat and speak. We still have to feed her but she can swallow by herself. The speech pathologist and physios have to help her until she gets stronger.‚Äù

Rushton and Rixon have one more thing in common -- they were both otherwise healthy. But this isn‚Äôt always the case.

‚ÄúSmoking and excessive drinking both increase the risk as does family history in a first-degree relative,‚Äù Nichols said.

The oral contraceptive, hormonal changes and hypertension can also have an impact.

‚ÄúFemales are at higher risk. And there‚Äôs a two-to-one prevalence in females to males,‚Äù Nichols said.

According to Nichols, the younger the patient, the higher their chance of survival -- granted they make it through the initial bleed.

While Rixon and Rushton can be considered two of the ‚Äúlucky‚Äù ones they don‚Äôt always see it that way.

Rixon says being told by medical professionals that he wouldn‚Äôt be able to sing again was the hardest part for him.

‚ÄúI initially had a paralysed vocal cord and I was a professional singer. I was miming words with an eyepatch thinking ‚Äòmaybe I‚Äôll be able to join [the Chicago tour] in a few months‚Äô, I just had no idea and when that realisation happened it was sad,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúMy voice was the way that I expressed myself and that had been cut off. But I proved them wrong.‚Äù

Rixon spent a total of five weeks in ICU and went through over a year of speech pathology and physiotherapy. He spent around four months in hospital and two and a half years in outpatient rehab.

Rushton doesn‚Äôt yet know what her recovery journey will look like, but her family and friends are proud of how far she‚Äôs come in such a short amount of time.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs so strong so we know she‚Äôll get through this,‚Äù Rushton said.

‚ÄúWe haven‚Äôt had the easiest 12 months. I know no-one deserves for this to happen, but she really doesn‚Äôt. She was just starting to get her life back on track, we moved to a new place, she just started dating someone new -- who happens to be her first ever boyfriend from when she was 17 -- so it‚Äôs been hard.‚Äù

Rushton‚Äôs family and friends have set up a GoFundMe page to help pay for rent and bills while she‚Äôs unable to work. To date, it‚Äôs had over $14,000 worth of donations.

‚ÄúMum works at Forest Lodge Cemetery in Leppington and helps people deal with the grief of losing loved ones. So now that the situation is flipped everyone is rallying around her because she‚Äôs always there for them.‚Äù

‚ÄúAt first, when we set up the fund, mum said she didn‚Äôt feel comfortable but when we explained that it would help look after Jaye and I she was a bit more OK with it,‚Äù Rushton said.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs been overwhelmed with the support, especially since income protection and insurance takes a while. Her work has been amazing and they‚Äôre still paying her and she has a lot of leave accrued so that helps.‚Äù

Now 30, Rixon has used his experience to help other young trauma sufferers connect. He launched the Gen Y United Survivor Network (Genyus Network) which is a digital platform for young trauma survivors and supporters that aims to optimise their quality of life and connect their experiences.

‚ÄúWhen it happened I felt a bit robbed of my identity. I felt like a victim but once I found hope I found a lot of different ways of engaging with people,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúWhen it comes to this stuff, young people aren‚Äôt the norm and it‚Äôs a bit scary to talk about it but people like me have a lot to say.‚Äù

Both Rushton and Rixon hope their experiences can help raise awareness around brain aneurysms so that others can recognise the symptoms.

‚ÄúIn Australia we don‚Äôt have headaches as a symptom on any of our stroke awareness campaigns,‚Äù Nichols said.

‚ÄúPeople don‚Äôt often alert professionals over a headache. They sit on them and assume it‚Äôs nothing. But if you‚Äôre getting headaches more frequently than normal you should see your GP.‚Äù

‚ÄúMy mum always had headaches and it‚Äôs scary to think it could have been that the whole time,‚Äù Rushton said. ‚ÄúI really hope this helps at least one person see a doctor sooner.‚Äù

To find your local GP click here. And for more information on brain aneurysms visit The Brain Foundation Australia.
TITLE: What Causes Brain Aneurysms? They Aren't Always As Sudden As They Seem

TEXT:
Frauke Petry sieht die AfD nach den Vorstandswahlen fest in der Hand des Rechtsau√üenfl√ºgels um Bj√∂rn H√∂cke

Mit Gauland in der Parteispitze h√§tte er nun eine zweite Marionette

Die wichtigsten Infos des Textes seht ihr zusammengefasst auch im Video oben

Die fr√ºhere AfD-Vorsitzende Frauke Petry sieht die Partei nach den Vorstandswahlen auf dem Parteitag in Hannover fest in der Hand des Rechtsau√üenfl√ºgels um den Th√ºringer AfD-Landesvorsitzenden Bj√∂rn H√∂cke. Mit Alexander Gauland in der Parteispitze h√§tte er nun eine zweite Marionette.

Der "Bild"-Zeitung sagte Petry: "Jetzt vollzieht sich, was Bj√∂rn H√∂cke schon immer angestrebt hat - mit Gauland eine zweite Marionette als Vorsitzenden zu haben."

Die AfD sei seit diesem Parteitag "jetzt faktisch in H√∂ckes Hand".

Der als gem√§√üigt geltende Berliner Landeschef Georg Pazderski sei "am Ende eben nur noch deshalb Vize-Chef von H√∂ckes Gnaden, weil er sich dem Fl√ºgel ergeben hat", so Petry weiter.

Die Gem√§√üigten in der Partei h√§tten "keinen Plan und keine Galionsfigur mehr", f√ºgte sie hinzu. "Den einzigen Anf√ºhrer, den sie noch h√§tten haben k√∂nnen, war Georg Pazderski, der ist demontiert."

Auf dem Parteitag in Hannover war Pazderski bei der Wahl zur neuen Doppelspitze gescheitert. Zwei Wahlg√§nge brachten keine Entscheidung, daraufhin entschloss sich am Samstagabend AfD-Fraktionschef Alexander Gauland zur Kandidatur. Der 76-J√§hrige bildet mit dem bisherigen Vorsitzenden J√∂rg Meuthen die neue Doppelspitze der Partei.
TITLE: Frauke Petry verr√§t: Der wahre Strippenzieher der AfD sitzt nicht in der Parteispitze

TEXT:
Getty

1. Pasha Kovalev‚Äôs former competitive dance partner is Anya Garnis, who joined ‚ÄòStrictly Come Dancing‚Äô as a pro for one series in 2013, where she partnered ‚ÄòCasualty‚Äô actor Patrick Robinson. 2. Pasha and Anya moved to the US in 2001 and began competing professionally, becoming US National Latin Finalists and Ohio Star Ball Finalists. 3. Pasha‚Äôs professional partner now is former ‚ÄòStrictly‚Äô dancer, Katya Virshilas, although he is touring with Anya in 2018. 4. Pasha was a contestant on the third series of Cat Deeley‚Äôs US dance show ‚ÄòSo You Think You Can Dance?‚Äô in 2007, where he finished in fifth place.

5. Pasha later served as a choreographer on the show for seven series, most recently appearing in 2014. 6. Pasha holds the record for the record for most perfect scores (8) on ‚ÄòStrictly‚Äô. 7. Pasha and Kevin jointly hold the record for the most tens ever awarded (61). 8. Pasha is in a long-term relationship with ‚ÄòCountdown‚Äô star Rachel Riley, after they were partnered on the show in 2013.

Doug Peters/EMPICS Entertainment Pasha Kovalev and Rachel Riley

9. Pasha hails from Siberia. 10. Oti Mabuse was previously a professional dancer on the German version of ‚ÄòStrictly‚Äô called ‚ÄòLet‚Äôs Dance!‚Äô in 2015. 11. Oti‚Äôs sister, Motsi, serves as a judge on the show, having previously been a professional dancer.

Rex/Shutterstock Motsi Mabuse on 'Let's Dance'

12. Oti studied Civil Engineering at university. 13. Oti is eight times South African Latin American Champion, and was also a semi-finalist in the World European Latin, World Cup, World Cup Freestyle Latin and European Championship Latin competitions. 14. Oti hails from born in Pretoria in South Africa. 15 Oti is married to Romanian dancer Marius Iepure, who has appeared as a background dancer on ‚ÄòStrictly‚Äô, most recently during Blackpool Week in 2017.

A post shared by Marius iepure (@mariusiepure) on Feb 26, 2016 at 11:27am PST

16. Kevin and Karen Clifton are married, having tied the knot in July 2015. 17. Kevin proposed to Karen on stage at a performance of ‚ÄòBurn The Floor‚Äô on her birthday. 18. Kevin set a new ‚ÄòStrictly‚Äô record in 2015 by becoming the first professional ever to reach the final for three consecutive years, and went on to beat this again the following year.

Karwai Tang via Getty Images Karen and Kevin Clifton

19. Kevin is a former Youth World Number 1 and four times British Latin Champion, also winning International Open titles in Italy, Germany, Spain, Portugal, Sweden, Japan, France, Hong Kong, Taiwan, Singapore, Slovenia, Slovakia, Finland and Belgium. 20. Kevin competed as a child with his sister Joanne, who also went on to become a ‚ÄòStrictly‚Äô professional in 2014. 21. Kevin and Joanne were taught to dance from an early age by their parents - former World Champions Keith and Judy Clifton. 22. Kevin retired from competitive dancing in 2007, and was ranked seventh in the world at the time.

Danny Lawson - PA Images via Getty Images Kevin and Karen with his sister Joanne

23. Kevin was previously married to fellow professional dancer Clare Craze, who he split from in 2010, with their divorce finalised three years later. 24. Kevin made his musical theatre debut in 2010, starring in a West End production of ‚ÄòDirty Dancing: The Musical‚Äô. 25. Kevin was previously a background dancer on ‚ÄòStrictly‚Äô in 2012, before being invited to join the pro cast a year later. 26. Karen Clifton is originally from Venezuela, but moved to New York when she was eight-years-old. 27. Karen has won numerous ballroom awards, including World Mambo Champion in 2008 and Professional American Rhythm Rising Star Champion in 2009. 28. Karen was married to fellow dancer Matthew Hauer prior to meeting Kevin. 29. Karen and Matthew previously auditioned for series six of ‚ÄòSo You Think You Can Dance?‚Äô in the US in 2009, and she reached the final six girls.

30. Karen and Kevin met in 2008, when they were cast as principal dancers in ‚ÄòBurn The Floor‚Äô, both on Broadway and in the West End. 31. Gorka Marquez is one of the top dancers in his native Spain. 32. Gorka represented his home country in the World Latin Championships in 2010, and reached the semi-finals of the 2012 WDSF World Cup. 33. Gorka is also a health and fitness enthusiast, regularly posting videos and pictures of his gym routines (and the results of them) on Instagram.

A post shared by Gorka Marquez (@gorka_marquez) on Sep 17, 2017 at 4:37am PDT

34. Nadiya Bychkova is a two-time World Champion and European Champion in ballroom and Latin ‚Äò10‚Äô Dance. She is also multiple-time Slovenian ballroom and Latin Champion. 35. Nadiya has previously taken part in the Bosnian version of ‚ÄòStrictly‚Äô, and can also do hip-hop dancing. 36. Nadiya was already pals with fellow professional dancer Alja≈æ Skorjanec, having trained at the same dance school in Slovenia. 37. Nadiya has a one-year-old daughter with partner Matija Skarabot, a famous Slovenian footballer who plays for Gorica.

Mike Marsland via Getty Images

38. Nadiya is also a model and has posed for Playboy. 39. Nadiya is originally from the Ukraine. 40. Alja≈æ ≈†korjanec and Janette Manrara are married, tying the knot in July 2017 after six years of dating.

A post shared by Alja≈æ ≈†korjanec (@aljazskorjanec) on Aug 1, 2017 at 7:19am PDT

41. Alja≈æ is a 19-time Slovenian champion in Ballroom, Latin and ‚Äô10‚Ä≤ Dance. 42. Alja≈æ was brought up in a small town in Slovenia where he started dancing aged five, signing himself up for dance lessons in nursery without his parents‚Äô knowledge. 43. Alja≈æ previously starred on Slovenia‚Äôs ‚ÄòDancing With the Stars‚Äô. 44. Janette Manrara auditioned for the fourth series of ‚ÄòSo You Think You Can Dance?‚Äô in 2008, but failed to make it into the top 20. She returned the following year and made it to the lives shows, but was eliminated in week seven.

45. Janette later appeared as a dancer in musical TV series ‚ÄòGlee‚Äô. 46. Janette has also worked on the Oscars and danced with Jennifer Lopez. 47. Janette started training as a dancer aged 19, but studied finance at Florida International University, and went on to work in a bank for seven years after graduating. 48. Janette is originally from Miami, with her family hailing from Cuba. 49. Giovanni Pernice has won various titles including the Italian Open Latin Dance Championships in 2012 with his dance partner Erika Attisano, and finished second place in the International Open Latin in Slovenia 2014. 50. Giovanni holds the ‚ÄòStrictly‚Äô record for getting the earliest ever 40 in the competition, which was in week seven of the 2017 series, for his Tango with Debbie McGee. 51. Giovanni went on to date ‚ÄòCoronation Street‚Äô star Georgia May Foote after they were paired together on the 2015 series. They split after less than a year together.

Dave J Hogan via Getty Images Giovanni Pernice and Georgia May Foote

52. Giovanni has a tattoo on his arm which reads ‚ÄòNato Per Vincere‚Äô meaning ‚ÄòBorn To Win‚Äô, as well as the date he won the Italian Championships on his wrist. 53. Giovanni was born in Sicily but moved to Bologna at the age of 14 to concentrate on dancing. 54. Giovanni holds the Guinness World Record for the most Jive kicks and flicks in 30 seconds after winning It Takes Two‚Äôs pro challenge in 2016.

55. Dianne Buswell has previously been crowned Australian Open Champion and is a four-time Amateur Australian Open Finalist. 56. Dianne was a pro on the last series of ‚ÄòDancing With The Stars Australia‚Äô in 2015, where she was fifth to be eliminated with partner Jude Bolton.

PA Archive/PA Images Dianne Buswell

57. AJ Pritchard was Strictly‚Äôs youngest ever male pro when he joined the show in 2016 at the age of 21. 58. AJ‚Äôs competitive partner is Chloe Hewitt, who is also one of the pro dancers. 59. AJ and Chloe have won titles including - deep breath - the British National Youth Latin Contest, the United Kingdom Youth Ballroom Championships, the Champions Of Tomorrow Youth Ballroom & Latin, and the all England Youth Ballroom & Latin tournament. 60. AJ and Chloe entered ‚ÄòBritain‚Äôs Got Talent‚Äô in 2013 as a dance act, and reached the live semi-finals.

A post shared by A J P R I T C H A R D (@aj11ace) on Oct 16, 2017 at 12:16am PDT

62. Chloe Hewitt joined the show with AJ in 2016, but has never had a celebrity partner during the two main series she has starred on. 63. Chloe has, however, danced with Gethin Jones on the 2016 Christmas special and Radzi Chinyanganya on the 2017 Children In Need special. 64. Chloe is the youngest ever female professional to have been on the show, being just 21 when she joined. 65. Anton Du Beke and Brendan Cole are the only two remaining original professionals, both appearing in the very first episode. 66. Anton is the oldest pro on the show, turning 51 in 2017. 67. Anton‚Äôs real name is Tony Beke. 68. Anton‚Äôs former competitive partner is former ‚ÄòStrictly‚Äô pro Erin Boag, and the couple continue to dance together outside of the show.

David Lodge via Getty Images Anton Du Beke with 'Strictly' host Tess Daly

69. Anton and Erin won the the New Zealand Championship two years in a row during the late 1990s. 70. Anton has only twice reached the ‚ÄòStrictly‚Äô final - once in the third series with Lesley Garrett, and then with Katie Derham in 2015. 71. Anton hold the record for the most number of 1s given out by the judges (4). 72. Anton used to work as a salesman prior to becoming a professional dancer. 73. Anton won the title of Rear Of The Year in 2011. 74. Anton and his wife Hannah welcomed twins in March 2017. 75. Brendan and Anton were both in the frame to replace Head Judge Len Goodman in 2017, but eventually lost out on the job to Shirley Ballas. 76. Brendan Cole won the very first series of ‚ÄòStrictly‚Äô with BBC newsreader Natasha Kaplinsky, and has only made the final once since with Lisa Snowdon in 2008.

BBC Brendan Cole with first partner Natasha Kaplinsky

77. Brendan is one of only two professionals to score a perfect 40 for a Cha Cha, with his and Lisa‚Äôs performance to ‚ÄòTears Dry On Their Own‚Äô in series six bagging him this title. 78. Brendan starred on ITV‚Äôs second series of ‚ÄòCelebrity Love Island‚Äô in 2006, where he finished runner-up with Kellie Bryan. 79. Brendan was a judge on New Zealand‚Äôs version of ‚ÄòStrictly‚Äô from 2005 to 2009, alongside Craig Revel Horwood, where they clashed even more frequently than they do on the UK show.

80. Brendan was a builder and roof layer prior to becoming a professional dancer. 81. Brendan appeared on Strictly‚Äôs predecessor ‚ÄòCome Dancing‚Äô alongside professional dance partner Camilla Dallerup, who also went on to become a ‚ÄòStrictly‚Äô pro. 82. Brendan and Camilla won the New Zealand and Asian Open Professional Championships and were semi-finalists at the International, UK Open, British Open and World Championships. 83. Brendan was born in Christchurch, New Zealand, but moved to the UK at the age of 18. 84. Brendan has a daughter, Aurelia, with wife Zoe Hobbs. 85. Katya Jones is originally from Saint Petersburg in Russia. Her mother is of Korean ethnicity, and her father is a Russian businessman. 86. Katya is married to fellow ‚ÄòStrictly‚Äô pro Neil Jones, tying the knot in 2013.

PA Wire/PA Images Neil and Katya Jones

87. Katya and Neil met in 2008 when her trainers (one of whom was former ‚ÄòStrictly‚Äô pro Karen Hardy) recommended Neil as a potential dance partner. 88. Katya and Neil won the WDC World Championships, as well as three titles at the World Amateur Latin Championships, before they finally turned pro in 2013. 89. Katya and Neil are now the undefeated four-time British National Champions. 90. Neil Jones has never had a celeb partner since joining the show in 2016, but paired up with Judy Murray on the 2017 Christmas special, and Olympian Hollie Webb and former ‚ÄòBlue Peter‚Äô presenter Konnie Huq on the 2016 and 2017 Children In Need Specials respectively. 91. Neil was born in a British Army Camp in Munster, Germany. 92. Neil has represented Finland, the Netherlands and the UK during the course of his competitive career. 93. Amy Dowden is the current British National Champion and one of the highest-ranking Ballroom and Latin American professional dancers in the UK.

Mike Marsland via Getty Images Amy Dowden

94. Amy is also a four-time British National Finalist and in 2015, she reached the semi-final of the World Championship. 95. Amy is the first ever Welsh professional on ‚ÄòStrictly‚Äô. 96. Pasha, Dianne, Karen, Kevin, Gorka, Janette, Alja≈æ have all appeared in the ‚ÄòBurn The Floor‚Äô dance production either on Broadway or the West End at some point during its run.
TITLE: 96 Things You Probably Didn't Know About The 'Strictly Come Dancing' Professional Dancers

TEXT:
D√≠a tras d√≠a salen a la luz casos de mujeres y hombres que han sido v√≠ctimas del acoso del productor cinematogr√°fico Harvey Weinstein. Tras a√±os tapando sus historias por miedo y dolor, cada vez son m√°s quienes se atreven a contar los abusos sufridos por Weinstein, pero tambi√©n por otros nombres de la industria como Kevin Spacey, el director Brett Ratner, el m√∫sico Nick Carter, el creativo de Pixar John Lasseter, el c√≥mico Louis C. K., los actores Jeffrey Tambor, Charlie Sheen o Silvester Stallone...

Sin embargo, hay quien sigue cuestionando a las v√≠ctima. En este caso, la que se ha mostrado cr√≠tica con los cientos de denunciantes ha sido la actriz Pamela Anderson. En una entrevista con la presentadora Megyn Kelly que se hizo p√∫blica en Estados Unidos el jueves, la protagonista de Baywatch se ha pronunciado al respecto, y de un modo no demasiado emp√°tico.

Como recoge The Daily Beast, la exconejita Playboy afirma que los casos tampoco son especialmente escandalosos porque "era ampliamente conocido que ciertos productores o cierta gente de Hollywood era gente que hab√≠a que evitar". Para rematar la faena, parece que Anderson culpa a las v√≠ctimas de Weinstein de lo sucedido: "Sabes d√≥nde te metes cuando entras sola en la habitaci√≥n de un hotel". Para ella, "no es excusa" afirmar que esos encuentros parec√≠an seguros porque hab√≠an sido acordados por los agentes de las ‚Äîsobre todo‚Äî actrices afectadas: "Creo que hab√≠a formas f√°ciles de ponerle remedio. No me parece una buena excusa".

La actriz asegura que en ocasiones le han ofrecido "dinero, casas, papeles en pel√≠culas" si se acostaba con hombres. "Aprend√≠ a no ponerme a m√≠ misma en esas situaciones. Cuando llegu√© a Hollywood, ten√≠a un mont√≥n de ofertas para hacer castings privados y cosas que no ten√≠an sentido, que se sal√≠an del sentido com√∫n", afirma en las declaraciones recogidas en el Daily Mail, y remata: "No entres sola en una habitaci√≥n de un hotel. Si alguien te abre la puerta en bata, vete".

Anderson asegura que no ha tenido nunca un encuentro cara a cara con Weinstein, pero que hablaron por tel√©fono en 2008 por una pel√≠cula y que le result√≥ "muy intimidante". "Me llam√≥ y me dijo: 'Peque√±a, tienes much√≠sima suerte de que te haya puesto en mi pel√≠cula, eres Pamela Anderson y no te mereces nada, y si no haces esto, nunca volver√°s a trabajar en esta ciudad".

Esa ha sido solo la primera parte de la entrevista, puesto que la segunda ‚Äîque se enfocar√° en su relaci√≥n con Julian Assange, el fundador de WikiLeaks‚Äî llegar√° este viernes 1 de diciembre.

Precisamente Anderson sufri√≥ abusos sexuales durante su infancia, como dio a conocer en 2014 en un discurso en Cannes, cuando cont√≥ que sus ni√±eras abusaron de ella entre los 6 y los 10 a√±os, y que fue violada a los 12. De ah√≠ que la conversaci√≥n acerca del esc√°ndalo Weinstein y sobre todos los casos similares que est√°n saltando en Hollywood tuviera a√∫n m√°s sentido, y que a muchos les haya chocado su culpabilizaci√≥n a las v√≠ctimas.

Este art√≠culo se public√≥ originalmente en El HuffPost
TITLE: Pamela Anderson culpa a las v√≠ctimas de Harvey Weinstein

Wurde das Ticket nicht rechtzeitig vor Fahrtantritt gekauft, entsteht f√ºr den Schwarzfahrer ein Bu√ügeld in H√∂he von 60 Euro.
Was passiert, wenn man einfach nur mit g√ºltigem Fahrschein in Berlin S-Bahn fahren will.
In einem von ihm verfassten Artikel in der "Bild"-Zeitung schreibt er, dass er noch am Bahnsteig stand als er das Ticket gekauft hat.
Auf Anfrage der "Bild"-Zeitung wurde das Verfahren von der S-Bahn Berlin gepr√ºft.

TEXT:
Geldstrafe, trotz Fahrschein

Die sogenannte "Zwei-Minuten-Regel" macht es m√∂glich

Mehr zu der Regel erfahrt ihr oben im Video

Wenn ihr euch das n√§chste Mal in Berlin ein E-Ticket kauft, solltet ihr ganz genau aufpassen. Sonst k√∂nnte es euch passieren, dass ihr schwarz fahrt ‚Äì trotz Ticket.

Bei der mobilen App der BVG in Berlin gibt es n√§mlich die sogenannte "Zwei-Minuten-Regel‚Äú. Fahrg√§ste m√ºssen sich rechtzeitig, also mindestens zwei Minuten vor Fahrtantritt, ein Ticket kaufen.

Diese Regel soll verhindern, dass sich Schwarzfahrer noch schnell ein Ticket kaufen k√∂nnen, sobald sie einen Kontrolleur erblicken. Wurde das Ticket nicht rechtzeitig vor Fahrtantritt gekauft, entsteht f√ºr den Schwarzfahrer ein Bu√ügeld in H√∂he von 60 Euro.

Wais beschwert sich bei der S-Bahn Berlin

Genau das ist "Bild"-Redakteur Jakob Wais passiert. Auf seinem Twitter Account berichtete der 28-J√§hrige von dem Vorfall. Er setzte sich auch schriftlich mit der S-Bahn Berlin in Verbindung.

Was passiert, wenn man einfach nur mit g√ºltigem Fahrschein in Berlin S-Bahn fahren will. Ich habe die @SBahnBerlin mal schriftlich um Kl√§rung gebeten. pic.twitter.com/VKCdZVjdZn ‚Äî Jakob Wais (@ich_Wais) 27. November 2017

Jakob Wais war vom Flughafen Berlin Sch√∂nefeld auf dem Weg nach Hause. In einem von ihm verfassten Artikel in der "Bild"-Zeitung schreibt er, dass er noch am Bahnsteig stand als er das Ticket gekauft hat. Er versuchte zwar, den Kontrolleur davon zu √ºberzeugen, die Diskussion war jedoch ohne Erfolg.

Als sich die Lebensgef√§hrtin des 28-J√§hrigen einschaltete, wurde der Kontrolleur ausf√§llig. Der Bahn-Mitarbeiter erkl√§rte das Ticket f√ºr ung√ºltig und Herr Wais musste die Geldstrafe akzeptieren.

Auf Anfrage der "Bild"-Zeitung wurde das Verfahren von der S-Bahn Berlin gepr√ºft.

Das Verfahren wurde eingestellt

Das Verfahren gegen ihn wurde mittlerweile aus Kulanz eingestellt. Die S-Bahn Berlin √§u√üerte sich zu dem Vorfall und entschuldigte sich au√üerdem f√ºr das Verhalten des Kontrolleurs gegen√ºber der Partnerin von Herrn Wais.

(best)
TITLE: Absurde "Zwei-Minuten-Regel": So werdet ihr zum Schwarzfahrer, obwohl ihr ein Ticket habt

Frauke Petry sieht die AfD nach den Vorstandswahlen fest in der Hand des Rechtsau√üenfl√ºgels um Bj√∂rn H√∂cke

Mit Gauland in der Parteispitze h√§tte er nun eine zweite Marionette

Die wichtigsten Infos des Textes seht ihr zusammengefasst auch im Video oben

Die fr√ºhere AfD-Vorsitzende Frauke Petry sieht die Partei nach den Vorstandswahlen auf dem Parteitag in Hannover fest in der Hand des Rechtsau√üenfl√ºgels um den Th√ºringer AfD-Landesvorsitzenden Bj√∂rn H√∂cke. Mit Alexander Gauland in der Parteispitze h√§tte er nun eine zweite Marionette.

Der "Bild"-Zeitung sagte Petry: "Jetzt vollzieht sich, was Bj√∂rn H√∂cke schon immer angestrebt hat - mit Gauland eine zweite Marionette als Vorsitzenden zu haben."

Die AfD sei seit diesem Parteitag "jetzt faktisch in H√∂ckes Hand".

Der als gem√§√üigt geltende Berliner Landeschef Georg Pazderski sei "am Ende eben nur noch deshalb Vize-Chef von H√∂ckes Gnaden, weil er sich dem Fl√ºgel ergeben hat", so Petry weiter.

Die Gem√§√üigten in der Partei h√§tten "keinen Plan und keine Galionsfigur mehr", f√ºgte sie hinzu. "Den einzigen Anf√ºhrer, den sie noch h√§tten haben k√∂nnen, war Georg Pazderski, der ist demontiert."

Auf dem Parteitag in Hannover war Pazderski bei der Wahl zur neuen Doppelspitze gescheitert. Zwei Wahlg√§nge brachten keine Entscheidung, daraufhin entschloss sich am Samstagabend AfD-Fraktionschef Alexander Gauland zur Kandidatur. Der 76-J√§hrige bildet mit dem bisherigen Vorsitzenden J√∂rg Meuthen die neue Doppelspitze der Partei.

TITLE: Bodas

SUMMARY:
Our terror of female power, and any unsettling of the patriarchal status quo, has been acutely visible in the current #MeToo moment.
As feminists brace for an anticipated backlash against the #MeToo movement, what‚Äôs particularly fascinating in Alderman‚Äôs novel is her assessment of how desperately the powerful cling to their privilege.
More convincing, and familiar, is how the existing male power structure organizes in defense of its own continued dominance.
But that‚Äôs still not enough, not in the face of all the institutional power men have accrued over generations.
But Alderman‚Äôs novel lays bare how difficult ‚Äï nearly impossible ‚Äï a just and equitable society is to conceive.
TEXT:
LITTLE BROWN AND COMPANY

This is how the patriarchy dies, not with a whimper but with a cataclysmic bang. One day, women wake up with a new power; their power is unprecedented and incomprehensible, exhilarating and frightening. It threatens the entire male-oriented structure that has defined most human civilizations throughout recorded history. In Naomi Alderman‚Äôs new speculative novel The Power, there‚Äôs a very literal, tangible power at work. Teen girls have mysteriously developed the ability to wield electricity with their fingers, and any older woman, once jolted by a young girl, can activate this power as well. Women, as a sex, have grown unimaginably dangerous. In every corner of the globe ‚Äï the U.S., India, Moldova, England, Nigeria ‚Äï women have found themselves with a physical strength that allows them to overpower men, even men who have long abused or controlled them. The Power, which originally came out in the U.K. in 2016, ended up arriving on American shores at an eminently relevant time. In a cultural moment dominated by the spectacle of abusive powerful men finally laid low by the stories of the women they victimized, women do seem to have a new weapon in the battle of the sexes. The question is, how much power do we have, and how much would it take to really change anything? From the outset, readers know how Alderman‚Äôs story ends. The Power is framed by correspondence between a supplicating male author, Neil, and a female author, Naomi, to whom he‚Äôs writing for thoughts on his historical novel manuscript, which constitutes the rest of the book. The letters in themselves are fascinating, revealing, as they quickly do, that the sexual power dynamics have been neatly flipped in this imagined future: Neil is ingratiating, flattering, apologetic over taking up Naomi‚Äôs time. His letter is postmarked from ‚ÄúThe Men Writers Association‚Äù and signed ‚ÄúMuch love.‚Äù Her response is flip and patronizing, deeming him a ‚Äúsaucy boy‚Äù for putting male soldiers and police officers into his book. ‚ÄúI think I‚Äôd rather enjoy this ‚Äòworld run by men‚Äô you‚Äôve been talking about,‚Äù she concludes. ‚ÄúSurely a kinder, more caring and ‚Äï dare I say it? ‚Äï more sexy world than the one we live in.‚Äù This letter from Naomi efficiently reveals one of Alderman‚Äôs dominant themes: A world run by women would be no kinder, more caring, or sexier than our current model. The titular power refers not only to the electrical force wielded by women in the novel, but the qualities of power itself ‚Äï how possessing power shapes us, allows us to become cruel and careless. Women, she posits, would not be too angelic to turn to violence and exploitation, if we could. If we had the power to get away with it. But though the corrupting ability of power is important, and aptly explored in The Power, it isn‚Äôt the most gripping and timely. As feminists brace for an anticipated backlash against the #MeToo movement, what‚Äôs particularly fascinating in Alderman‚Äôs novel is her assessment of how desperately the powerful cling to their privilege, and how much force is needed to unseat a hegemony as deeply rooted as the patriarchy. Our terror of female power, and any unsettling of the patriarchal status quo, has been acutely visible in the current #MeToo moment. If women, instead of men, are the adjudicators of truth, then won‚Äôt men be injured? We fear overcorrection, men ousted from the industries they love based on unfair or misleading accusations, an abandonment of due process. Some, like Masha Gessen, have warned of a ‚Äúsex panic.‚Äù More disturbingly, innumerable men have hinted that the current wave of sexual harassment accusations and attendant firings is akin to a witch hunt, rather than a form of long-delayed justice. Others, like Erin Gloria Ryan and Rebecca Traister, have cautioned women to be prepared for an inevitable backlash as male power reasserts itself. ‚ÄúYou can feel the backlash brewing,‚Äù Traister wrote in The Cut recently. ‚ÄúAll it will take is one particularly lame allegation ‚Äî and given the increasing depravity of the charges, the milder stuff looks lamer and lamer, no matter how awful the experience ‚Äî to turn the tide from deep umbrage on behalf of women to pity for the poor, bullied men.‚Äù Not only that, she noted, but the natural inclination of men in the workplace would be to limit women‚Äôs rights and opportunities in order to protect themselves from accusations. ‚ÄúMany men will absorb the lessons of late 2017 to be not about the threat they‚Äôve posed to women but about the threat that women pose to them,‚Äù she wrote. ‚ÄúSo there will be more ‚Äî perhaps unconscious ‚Äî hesitancy about hiring women, less eagerness to invite them to lunch, or send them on work trips with men.‚Äù The reaction to women gaining power will be to push them back down, even if unintentionally.

As feminists brace for an anticipated backlash against the #MeToo movement, what‚Äôs particularly fascinating in Alderman‚Äôs novel is her assessment of how desperately the powerful cling to their privilege.

Alderman‚Äôs novel-within-a-novel follows a far-flung cast of characters ‚Äï Roxy, the daughter of a British organized crime don; Allie, a girl who flees an abusive foster family in the American South and is reborn as Mother Eve, a messianic religious leader; Tunde, a male journalist from Nigeria; Margot Cleary, the mayor of a major city ‚Äï as they negotiate the new world order, one in which women, not men, have the superior physical strength. There‚Äôs not much recognizable similarity between the matriarchy society that unfolds in The Power and the U.S. in 2017 ‚Äï but the uneasy, suspicious approach to female power jumps off the page. After Cleary‚Äôs electric force is jolted awake by her young daughter, Jocelyn, she‚Äôs simultaneously strengthened and made vulnerable by it. She‚Äôs bolder in meetings (‚ÄúNothing that either of these men says is really of great significance,‚Äù she muses during one, ‚Äúbecause she could kill them in three moves‚Äù) but she also stands to lose her position if her power is discovered. As soon as the pervasive threat of young women‚Äôs ability became clear to the government, new regulations cropped up to keep them controlled. Public schools are segregated by gender. Women with the power are barred from most public offices. It‚Äôs all for safety ‚Äï the safety, above all, of men, which is achieved by limiting the rights of the dangerous gender, not the endangered. The goal is to support the status quo, ‚Äútrying to keep everything normal, to keep people feeling safe and going to their jobs and spending their dollars on weekend recreational activities,‚Äù and that means keeping girls and women subordinate. ‚ÄúWhen the power first came,‚Äù says a young man who serves in the palace of a new Eastern European rebel leader, ‚Äúthe men there, the warlords, blinded all the girls. That is what I heard. They put their eyes out with hot irons. So they could still be the bosses, you see?‚Äù It‚Äôs late in The Power, several years into the fallout of women‚Äôs new capability, and the power dynamics have begun to shift. This male servant was just made to lick splintered glass off the floor after interrupting the rebel leader, Tatiana Moskalev, as she tells a joke to her guests. Moskalev‚Äôs new country, Bessapara, was wrenched out of Moldova, an impoverished Eastern European country notorious for the prevalence of sex trafficking. With their new powers, the women and girls of the country were at last able to wreak vengeance on men who abused and imprisoned them, and even to take control themselves. But that control is not given easily, despite the deadliness of their new abilities. Men, fearful of once-vulnerable women, find ways to make them vulnerable again ‚Äï laws that confine women, defenses that will allow them to survive the electric shocks, stores of heavy weaponry to overpower women‚Äôs sparks. One of the least convincing aspects of The Power is how quickly women and men ‚Äï but especially women ‚Äï create and take on new gender roles. A role-reversing flip in power would, of course, shift gender roles, but Alderman paints it as near-immediate, despite the lifetimes of conditioning, and long-standing patriarchal power structures, each girl and woman have already absorbed. ‚ÄúThere are strange movements arising now,‚Äù Alderman writes, just a year or so into the narrative. ‚ÄúBoys dressing as girls to seem more powerful. Girls dressing as boys to shake off the meaning of the power, or to leap on the unsuspecting, wolf in sheep‚Äôs clothing.‚Äù By the time a handful of years have passed, a new culture has sprung up: Advertisements that depict strong, commanding girls flaunting their sparks, to the admiration of boys; sprawling networks of female mercenary soldiers; a woman politician openly leering at handsome young journalists and aides; a woman stealing and taking credit for the reporting of her male colleague. This all seems to happen with remarkable speed, compared with, say, how slowly the American political system has adjusted to the reality that more than half of contemporary voters are women. (We got the vote decades ago, and still no woman president ‚Äï just saying.) More convincing, and familiar, is how the existing male power structure organizes in defense of its own continued dominance. Men brutalize women to ensure their continued subservience, or they hack out the mysterious organ from which the electricity surges and implant them in their own bodies, or they gather unconquerable coalitions of government force to overwhelm the female upstarts. The world has destabilized, but that doesn‚Äôt mean women are winning the fight to realign it. It‚Äôs a grim vision. Alderman‚Äôs novel is lurid with gruesome murders and massacres, superfluous torture and exploitation. Men are cracking down on women in hopes of reestablishing their primacy, but women have become equally bloodthirsty in hopes of seizing control. Perhaps the most terrifying thing about dystopia is how perilously close it can come to utopia. We long to reimagine our world into something more just, more safe, more free, but the cost can‚Äôt be ignored: new injustices, new cruelties, new restrictions on human freedom and feeling. Justice, safety and freedom are not distributed equally; a realignment might look utopian to some, dystopian to others. (Extreme proponents of Christian theocracy might look on the Republic of Gilead, the setting of Margaret Atwood‚Äôs The Handmaid‚Äôs Tale, far more charitably than feminists.) How do we solve the flaws in our societies without creating newer, greater flaws? What counts as an improvement, and to whom? As I read The Power, I found myself ambivalent as to whether the novel qualified as a dystopia or a utopia. It‚Äôs casually, and understandably, described as a dystopia in The Washington Post, Harper‚Äôs Bazaar, The Guardian and other publications. But why, exactly? Is it dystopian to imagine our own patriarchal society in mirror image? A toxic matriarchy can‚Äôt really be any worse than what we have now. Yet, by the same token, surely it‚Äôs not better. Which is to say, it‚Äôs not better on the whole; it would probably be better for women. That, in itself, is perhaps the terrifying thing: A world in which women and people of color are routinely disenfranchised, their freedoms curtailed by extrajudicial and judicial violence and discrimination, has long been acceptable to us. What often terrifies, in a dystopia, is similar lack of freedom being visited on the people in charge ‚Äï what if white people were treated like black people, or men like women?

As in The Power, a display of female power, like that of the #MeToo movement, invites a crackdown; the crackdown, in turn, reveals that this whole time we didn‚Äôt have equality, but a begrudging tolerance based on our willingness to cede men the ultimate say. If we insist, at long last, that men not be allowed to sexually terrorize women in the workplace, we are a threat, and threats are to be crushed. In Alderman‚Äôs book, the threat is not so easy to crush. Intoxicated by their new strength, women torture and kill men who raped or abused them. Men and boys become viscerally fearful of the women and girls in their lives, in the same inescapable, unceasing way women now fear men. But that‚Äôs still not enough, not in the face of all the institutional power men have accrued over generations. ‚ÄúThe world is trying to go back to its former shape,‚Äù thinks Allie, toward the end of the novel. ‚ÄúEverything we‚Äôve done is not enough. There are still men with money and influence who can shape things to their will.‚Äù She‚Äôs speaking with a mysterious inner voice, which has guided her throughout her rise to religious leadership. ‚ÄúYou want the whole world turned upside down,‚Äù the voice tells her. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt get there from here. You‚Äôll have to start again.‚Äù There‚Äôs only one answer, Allie finally realizes: An apocalyptic war that will shatter all the existing norms, institutions, governments and other structures built by and for men. ‚ÄúThe women will die just as much as the men will if we bomb ourselves back to the Stone Age,‚Äù someone warns her. ‚ÄúAnd then we‚Äôll be in the Stone Age,‚Äù she responds. ‚ÄúAnd then there will be five thousand years of rebuilding, five thousand years where the only thing that matters is: can you hurt more, can you do more damage, can you instill fear ... And then the women will win.‚Äù The thing that will really end the patriarchy isn‚Äôt an incremental shift, a demand for rights, a few skirmishes ‚Äï it‚Äôs Armageddon. The endgame of feminism isn‚Äôt to replace the patriarchy with a matriarchy; another system of injustice isn‚Äôt the goal. But Alderman‚Äôs novel lays bare how difficult ‚Äï nearly impossible ‚Äï a just and equitable society is to conceive. A reversal of power might leave the other team in charge, but we‚Äôre dreaming if we think that women are immune to abusing their power. Either way, the reality remains: One gender has the power, and as long as they have the power, any ‚Äúequality‚Äù is offered as appeasement and can be revoked if we ‚Äúbotch‚Äù our plea for justice. And, as we uneasily ponder a backlash, that is exactly what we‚Äôre contemplating. There are women in power now, but not many; the vast majority of top executives and government officials are men ‚Äï and certainly there‚Äôs been no change as to which gender has, on average, the ability to physically overpower the other. Should men decide to stop this bloodletting of abusive cads, then that‚Äôs what will happen. This reckoning is happening on sufferance, and that‚Äôs why we wait anxiously for something to go wrong ‚Äï a false accusation, the wrong man getting fired ‚Äï so that the men in charge have a clear excuse to shut the whole thing down. Of course, women do have some power, and that‚Äôs why we need to be placated, convinced not to think about more extreme measures of retribution. We have voting rights, and we outnumber men. We have purchasing power. We have the weapons to strike at the patriarchal system, to boycott Weinstein Company movies and the ‚ÄúToday‚Äù show or to vote wave after wave of women into office. We can make things very uncomfortable for men, if they don‚Äôt give us some taste of justice, some hint of equity. But we‚Äôre not in charge. ‚ÄúRemember, sweetheart,‚Äù Allie‚Äôs voice tells her again and again, ‚Äúthe only way you‚Äôre safe is if you own the place.‚Äù In The Power, women can finally own the place, if at a staggering cost. But in this reality, women don‚Äôt own the place, or even co-own it, and we probably never will. There‚Äôs nothing more dystopian than that.
TITLE: A Feminist Dystopia For The #MeToo Moment

Frauke Petry sieht die AfD nach den Vorstandswahlen fest in der Hand des Rechtsau√üenfl√ºgels um Bj√∂rn H√∂cke

Die wichtigsten Infos des Textes seht ihr zusammengefasst auch im Video oben

Die fr√ºhere AfD-Vorsitzende Frauke Petry sieht die Partei nach den Vorstandswahlen auf dem Parteitag in Hannover fest in der Hand des Rechtsau√üenfl√ºgels um den Th√ºringer AfD-Landesvorsitzenden Bj√∂rn H√∂cke. Mit Alexander Gauland in der Parteispitze h√§tte er nun eine zweite Marionette.

Auf dem Parteitag in Hannover war Pazderski bei der Wahl zur neuen Doppelspitze gescheitert.
