SUMMARY:
A new video from The Representation Project is highlighting the courageous people who told their stories of sexual harassment, assault and rape these past few weeks.
The video, titled ‚Äú2017: Silent No Longer,‚Äù is part of the social justice organization‚Äôs annual end-of-year video roundups, which usually highlight the damaging affects of gender stereotypes.
This year, however, Jennifer Siebel Newsom, founder and CEO of The Representation Project, decided to pay homage to the survivors who spoke out this year.
"For too long, victims like myself have been forced to stay silent, swallowing our trauma in shame or fear of retaliation," Newsom said in a press release.
TEXT:
A new video from The Representation Project is highlighting the courageous people who told their stories of sexual harassment, assault and rape these past few weeks.

The video, titled ‚Äú2017: Silent No Longer,‚Äù is part of the social justice organization‚Äôs annual end-of-year video roundups, which usually highlight the damaging affects of gender stereotypes. This year, however, Jennifer Siebel Newsom, founder and CEO of The Representation Project, decided to pay homage to the survivors who spoke out this year.

"For too long, victims like myself have been forced to stay silent, swallowing our trauma in shame or fear of retaliation," Newsom said in a press release.
TITLE: Powerful Video Honors The Sexual Violence Survivors Who Told Their Stories In 2017

SUMMARY:
Imagen contenida en el informe de la OIM en la que se ve a un grupo de subsaharianos retenidos en Sabha, en el sur de Libia.
Los que est√°n fuera de esos muros, muchos miles, son los que se exponen a la esclavitud y la violencia.
Los que venden suelen ser ghaneses y nigerianos y los que compran, libios.
Y es que la prioridad de la la Uni√≥n en Libia ha sido m√°s la de poner barreras, la de impedir que salga m√°s flujo de migrantes, que la de garantizar que se les trata dignamente.
"Lo que ya era una situaci√≥n nefasta ahora se ha vuelto catastr√≥fica", reproch√≥ el d√≠a que se conoci√≥ el v√≠deo de la subasta humana.
TEXT:
Lo sab√≠an hasta en las m√°s altas esferas, de la UE a la ONU, desde hace meses, muchos, pero ha tenido que ser la CNN la que ponga en la agenda urgente del mundo la verg√ºenza de lo que pasa en Libia: la subasta de inmigrantes y refugiados como esclavos.

Un v√≠deo difundido el pasado 14 de noviembre -de escasa luz, mal encuadre y contenido clar√≠simo- mostraba a un grupo de j√≥venes africanos en fila mientras una voz en alto lanzaba cifras. No era la sala Christie's de Nueva York buscando comprador para el Salvator Mundi de Leonardo Da Vinci. Era un lugar sin identificar del pa√≠s norteafricano, donde en pleno siglo XXI se pone a√∫n en la picota a seres humanos, mercanc√≠a para trabajar sin descanso o para convertirse en juguetes sexuales de sus amos.

La Organizaci√≥n Internacional para las Migraciones (OIM) denunci√≥ por primera vez en abril la existencia de "mercados de esclavos" donde se "venden" inmigrantes en Libia, pero s√≥lo se movieron e indignaron las ONG. Luego lanz√≥ un informe, en verano, que tambi√©n pas√≥ con m√°s pena que gloria, y eso que ya inclu√≠a testimonios estremecedores de algunas de las v√≠ctimas localizadas. Palabras perdidas en el eco de los despachos. Pero ahora ha llegado una investigaci√≥n period√≠stica de primer nivel y su ruido no se puede amortiguar. La comunidad internacional ha tenido que pararse a escuchar c√≥mo se pide entre 400 y 800 euros por persona. ¬ø"D√≥nde est√° el mundo?", se preguntaba la cadena de noticias norteamericana. Ahora, al fin, tratando de buscar soluciones.

QU√â EST√Å PASANDO

Lo que ha documentado la OIM y la CNN es que en la √∫ltima etapa en el continente africano de quienes tratan de llegar a Europa cruzando el Mediterr√°neo -esa fosa en la que este a√±o ya han muerto m√°s de 3.000 personas, denuncia CEAR- los hombres y mujeres, inmigrantes y refugiados, son expuestos, comprados y explotados.

Los migrantes, sobre todo los m√°s j√≥venes, son vendidos para trabajar en casas, naves y talleres clandestinos o abandonados en apariencia, como cebo para exigir un rescate a sus familias y tambi√©n, en el caso de las mujeres y ni√±as, como esclavas sexuales o prostitutas. Seg√∫n el informe de la OIM -una organizaci√≥n asociada a las Naciones Unidas- estas personas son llevadas a plazas p√∫blicas o garajes en distintos puntos de Libia, donde se muestran a los posibles compradores.

Su precio oscila entre los 200 y los 500 d√≥lares (entre 171 y 429 euros, aproximadamente) y se paga m√°s por los sanos, por las mujeres guapas y por quien tuviera una formaci√≥n u oficio previos, de alba√±iles a pintores, pasando por azulejeros, granjeros, recolectores, carpinteros...

No todos los esclavos cobran por la labor que desarrollan a la fuerza. Algunos no pasan de tener un mal techo y peor comida con sus due√±os-captores. Algunos logran escapar, otros est√°n entre dos y tres meses con sus compradores y otros, malviven encerrados en √°reas donde son forzados a trabajar sin descanso, indica el estudio, hecho con investigadores a pie de campo, como el reporte de la CNN. Los supervivientes de esta experiencia sufren malnutrici√≥n severa y traumas por los abusos y maltratos de todo tipo, incluyendo los sexuales. Se desconoce cu√°ntos de ellos mueren durante su cautiverio. Desde principios de a√±o, casi mil solicitantes de asilo y refugio han sido liberados.

(Puedes seguir leyendo tras la foto...).

Imagen contenida en el informe de la OIM en la que se ve a un grupo de subsaharianos retenidos en Sabha, en el sur de Libia.

¬øD√ìNDE EST√Å EL GOBIERNO LIBIO?

William Lacy Swing, el director general de la OIM, se√±al√≥ este martes desde Ginebra, en una videoconferencia con el Consejo de Seguridad de la ONU, que cerca de 400.000 personas est√°n atrapadas en Libia, tratando de hacerse a la mar. De ellas, apenas 15.000 est√°n en unos 30 centros pseudo-oficiales, que en muchos casos no cumplen ni con las condiciones b√°sicas de higiene. Los que est√°n fuera de esos muros, muchos miles, son los que se exponen a la esclavitud y la violencia.

¬øPor qu√© el Gobierno libio no ataja esta bestialidad? Pues porque realmente no hay una administraci√≥n estable y seria. El pa√≠s est√° sumido en un formidable caos desde la llamada primavera y la intervenci√≥n de la OTAN que acab√≥ con la salida del poder en 2011 de Muammar el Gadafi; pr√°cticamente hay con dos gobiernos de facto: el oficial, el de unidad nacional del presidente Fayez al-Sarraj, y el llamado Congreso Nacional General del Tr√≠poli, islamista, dominado por los Hermanos Musulmanes y que act√∫a como contrapoder, controlando la capital y la mitad occidental del estado. A eso se a√±ade el poder local de grupos rebeldes, tribales y otras derivadas yihadistas.

Esa confusi√≥n es la que aprovechan los contrabandistas y los traficantes de personas para mover a los migrantes -en su inmensa mayor√≠a subsaharianos-. A unos los llevan finalmente hasta la costa, en busca de precarias embarcaciones con las que tratar de cruzar a Europa, y a otros los secuestran y subastan. Los que venden suelen ser ghaneses y nigerianos y los que compran, libios.

El gobierno oficial ha anunciado, presionado por las informaciones de la prensa, que va a emprender una investigaci√≥n sobre estas ventas, para dar con las mafias, identificar el lugar donde retienen a los rehenes y tratar de devolverlos a sus pa√≠ses.

Las principales ONG y organismos internacionales se lamentan de lo complicado que es trabajar en este contexto. "Los avances son modestos, la seguridad sigue siendo vol√°til, el acceso a los lugares clave no es posible a diario y las operaciones de la ONU contin√∫an siendo realizados a distancia desde Tunez", lamenta Swing.

¬øY QU√â HA HECHO LA UE?

Lamentarse. Su alta representante para la Pol√≠tica Exterior, Federica Mogherini, ha condenado el trato "inhumano" y la "esclavizaci√≥n" de inmigrantes en Libia a trav√©s de un comunicado del Servicio Europeo de Acci√≥n Exterior. Ha hablado de la necesidad de "garantizar el respeto de los derechos humanos y mejorar las condiciones de vida" de estas personas. Poco m√°s por ahora. Y es que la prioridad de la la Uni√≥n en Libia ha sido m√°s la de poner barreras, la de impedir que salga m√°s flujo de migrantes, que la de garantizar que se les trata dignamente.

Est√° llegando dinero para que la Armada impida la salida de las pateras y ese mayor control es que, por ejemplo, ha reducido a la mitad la llegada de desplazados a Italia, que adem√°s est√° limitando la labor de las ONG en la zona. Eso est√° haciendo que la ruta vire a Marruecos y Argelia y, de ah√≠, a Espa√±a, donde se est√°n alcanzando a cifras de hace casi 10 a√±os.

De hecho, el alto comisionado de la ONU para los Derechos Humanos, Zeid Ra'ad al Hussein, ha llegado a denunciar la "inhumana" la cooperaci√≥n de la Uni√≥n Europea con la Guardia Costera de Libia. "El sufrimiento de los inmigrantes detenidos en Libia es una atrocidad para la conciencia humana", afirm√≥ en un comunicado. "Lo que ya era una situaci√≥n nefasta ahora se ha vuelto catastr√≥fica", reproch√≥ el d√≠a que se conoci√≥ el v√≠deo de la subasta humana.

Espa√±a inst√≥ la pasada semana Libia a cumplir la Convenci√≥n de la ONU contra el Crimen Transnacional organizado y su protocolo sobre trata de seres humanos.

(Puedes seguir leyendo tras la foto...).

Varios n√°ufragos tratan de mantenerse a flote mientras los rescatan las autoridades de Malta, a 15 millas n√°uticas de Zawiya (Libya), el pasado 14 de abril.

¬øY QU√â SE PUEDE HACER AHORA?

Por primera vez, el Consejo de Seguridad de la ONU ha tratado esta semana el tema de Libia. Tanto el OIM como el Alto Comisionado para los Refugiados, pidieron en esa reuni√≥n "medidas concretas" para acabar con "estos graves abusos que no pueden ser ignorados", en palabras de Filippo Grandi, m√°ximo responsable del Acnur.

La soluci√≥n debe ser global, desde la pol√≠tica, la seguridad, los derechos humanos... Por eso no les vale que s√≥lo se mire al control de fronteras, taponar las salidas, vigilar las embarcaciones. "Demasiado a menudo -denuncian- se centran las medidas en controlar, disuadir y excluir". Hay que "humanizar" las pol√≠ticas. Tres decisiones de hacen urgentes: crear un sistema de recepci√≥n de migrantes adecuado, crear m√°s plazas para su reasentamiento y trabajar acciones conjuntas contra los traficantes de personas.

Todo ello debe concretarse, proponen, en nuevas sanciones como la congelaci√≥n de activos y la prohibici√≥n de viajes a personas relacionadas con las mafias, incautaci√≥n de fondos y materiales de las redes de contrabandistas y m√°s dureza por v√≠a judicial -para lo que har√≠a falta un estado s√≥lido y no las milicias islamistas que justo ahora controlan el sistema judicial local-. William Lacy Swing lo resume en dos apuestas: actuar contra las redes y proteger a los migrantes. "La comunidad internacional dispone de todos los elementos necesarios para atajar el problema", dice, y "lo √∫nico que se necesita es un acuerdo claro" entre las partes implicadas. "Esta es una enorme tragedia humana y podemos detenerla", sostiene sin dudas.

Habr√≠a que implicar a la Uni√≥n Africana, a Libia y los pa√≠ses de origen para registrar a los desplazados, darles documentos de viaje y que algunos terceros pa√≠ses los acojan. Ruanda se ha ofrecido a atender a 30.000 migrantes.

Trilateral meeting #EU - #AU - #UN with @MoussaFaki_M @antonioguterres @JunckerEU to reinforce joint action to help migrants in #Libya #AUEU pic.twitter.com/lzcHrfKq2D
TITLE: Libia, el infierno donde se venden esclavos a 400 euros

SUMMARY:
Dave Warner, like the selectors, is only too happy to push the career of Cameron Bancroft forward.
And Australia's selectors were right.
Paine didn't star with either bat or gloves, yet he played his part.
After going cheaply in the first innings, all the pressure was on the slender shoulders of 25-year-old West Australian Cameron Bancroft.
There was also that moment in the field earlier when Bancroft didn't flinch as a ball struck with great force thwocked into his helmet at short leg.
TEXT:
Dave Warner, like the selectors, is only too happy to push the career of Cameron Bancroft forward.

You were wrong.

If you're the sort of person who reads only the first line because you have a short attention span, that's it. That's all you need to know. If you didn't like the changes which the national selectors made to the Australian line-up ahead of the first Ashes Test against England at The Gabba (which Australia just won by ten wickets), then you were wrong.

And Australia's selectors were right.

Two much-loved sports dominate the Australian summer cultural landscape. One is cricket. The other is selector bashing -- a rudimentary, bare-knuckled form of brutality at which every Australian sports lover excels.

Selector-bashing is the greatest sport on earth because you can't lose. If the players blow it, well obviously it was the fault of those damned selectors. You are vindicated. You are a genius. If the team plays well, the conversation just got changed for you and no one cares or remembers how aggrieved you were five days ago.

The selector bashers were out in force last week when Tim Paine, Shaun Marsh and Cameron Bancroft were added to the Australian lineup. They continued to feel extra good about themselves when Paine dropped a tough but very catchable catch early in this match, when Marsh grassed one on the boundary, and when Bancroft fell cheaply in Australia's first innings.

Then a funny thing happened while everyone was swimming in their big bubbly pool of schadenfraude.

Shaun Marsh: Unfashionable but effective.

Marsh dug in with the bat. Selectors wanted a man at number six who would provide solidity. They didn't want a "maybe man" as likely to make a duck as decimate an attack. They wanted a no-nonsense guy who would be a barrier between the sketchy upper order and the tail. A rock, not a fire-cracker. And Marsh was that.

At 34, and on his eighth recall to the team, the elder Marsh brother showed that all his international experience counted for something. Like Steve Smith, he assessed the rhythm of this game, and rightly judged that it was a siege, not an assault. He didn't last as long as Smith -- because who did? -- but in making 51 of 141 balls, he absolutely did his job.

Paine's contributions were of a different nature. Selectors were stuck between the encumbent wicket keeper who wasn't performing, the guy before him who didn't do much either, plus a bunch of young no-names. They went for a pick so left of left field, he was almost in right field.

"He has performed well for us whenever he has represented Australia in any format," chief selector Trevor Hohns said of Paine ahead of this match, and what Paine brought was cricket smarts.

It was Paine's appeal -- while his teammates stood silent and largely disinterested -- which led to the controversial stumping of Moeen Ali. Again it was his urging which resulted in Stuart Broad's demise from a feathered-edge. Paine didn't star with either bat or gloves, yet he played his part.

After going cheaply in the first innings, all the pressure was on the slender shoulders of 25-year-old West Australian Cameron Bancroft. He responded, bringing up his 50 off 111 watchful, straight-batted balls.

"He looked right at home, didn't he," was Smith's assessment of his debutant opener in the post-match interviews with Channel 9.

There was also that moment in the field earlier when Bancroft didn't flinch as a ball struck with great force thwocked into his helmet at short leg. It may well be that he had no time to react, so firmly was the ball struck. Yet this moment gave great weight to Hohns' assessment that he is "a very talented and tough cricketer who shows a good temperament for Test cricket".

This could all unravel as soon as this coming Saturday, when the second Test (a day-nighter) starts in Adelaide. Indeed, this could all have been irrelevant had Steve Smith not compiled one of the great Ashes centuries.

But the fact is, Smith still needed guys around him adding whatever lesser skills they could bring. He found them. Or rather, the selectors found them for him. Credit where it's due. Those bastard selectors got something right for a change.
TITLE: The Ashes: A Few Choice Words For Everybody Who Bagged The Aussie Cricket Selectors

SUMMARY:
Music venues and festivals have been called upon to do more to stamp out groping and sexual harassment at gigs, after a string of well-publicised assaults at Australian concerts.
Dr Bianca Fileborn is a lecturer in criminology at the University of NSW, with research focusing on safety, unwanted sexual attention and sexual violence at music venues.
After forming a Facebook group to share issues in the Melbourne music scene, Marcou said she was shocked to see how common sexual harassment was in the current music industry.
There isn't enough mention of sexual harassment in security training courses, so we need to influence training curriculum."
They must be aware of the full behaviours that constitute sexual harassment and assault."
TEXT:
Music venues and festivals have been called upon to do more to stamp out groping and sexual harassment at gigs, after a string of well-publicised assaults at Australian concerts.

The spotlight has been shone on the often under-reported elements of abuse and harassment in music in recent times, with a series of artists calling out bad behaviour from the stage during their gigs and victims speaking out on social media.

Australian bands Luca Brasi and Camp Cope have repeatedly called out such behaviour at their concerts, with Camp Cope starting their own campaign named 'It Takes One' to raise awareness about assaults and violence against women happening at concerts, and enlisting popular Australian acts like Frenzal Rhomb, The Jezabels and Triple J host Dom Alessio.

During a concert on his recent Aussie tour, Canadian rapper Drake called out from the stage to a man allegedly seen groping a woman in the moshpit, loudly saying, "If you don't stop touching girls I'm gonna come out there and f**k you up", while similar public shaming has been directed at alleged sexual harassers by musicians including punk band Architects and U.K. artist Loyle Carner.

Last summer in Australia saw a series of alleged sex assaults at the Falls Festival in Tasmania, and the launch of a dedicated phone line at the Laneway Festival for music fans experiencing or witnessing bad behaviour.

Dr Bianca Fileborn is a lecturer in criminology at the University of NSW, with research focusing on safety, unwanted sexual attention and sexual violence at music venues. She is appearing on a panel titled 'Safe Spaces' on Wednesday at Sydney's Electronic Music Conference, examining how venues can do better in keeping patrons safe.

"It's something that has always happened but we're starting to talk about it more and call it out. We're starting to see a cultural social shift within the music industry, with more women, and gender and sexuality-diverse people, coming into the scene and having a voice, being able to draw attention to this behaviour," she told HuffPost Australia.

"They've harnessed the platform they have really well, putting things in place to generate furious change within the industry. It has coincided with internet online activism, giving more spaces for people to be sharing their experiences and calling things out. They're also doing so collectively, so it's not just one person saying they've been felt up in a moshpit, suddenly everyone can share their experiences and we can see it's a more pervasive pattern of behaviour and not just one-off isolated incidents."

Fileborn said groping in moshpits and unwanted sexual comments had been "completely normalised" in the Australian music scene, to the point where women tried to combat such unwanted attention by -- for instance -- wearing tight-fitting clothes to deter people trying to grope their breasts or genitals.

"In my research on licensed venues, most people expected it, it was seen as part of what you had to put up with and the price you pay to be a woman in a venue," she said.

"Definitely those types of harassment are trivialised and not seen as a big deal. People say maybe it's annoying, but you put up with it and move on. That trivialisation is affirmed by responses from people and venues. How venues respond is mixed but most times they will be dismissed. Some venues respond very well and take it seriously, some are terrible."

Fans at the Splendour In The Grass festival, 2016 in Byron Bay

Helen Marcou is a Melbourne-based music activist, one of the organisers of the successful Save Live Australia's Music (SLAM) movement and co-owner of the popular Bakehouse Studios. She has also been involved with Victorian venues implementing stronger safeguards to protect against bad behaviour at gigs. After forming a Facebook group to share issues in the Melbourne music scene, Marcou said she was shocked to see how common sexual harassment was in the current music industry.

"I was so disappointed to see it was so intrinsic and prevalent in our community. It was the fact our performers were not safe in their own workplace, and not afforded same protections as other workers in other industries," she told HuffPost Australia.

"We've got to look at decreasing this. There needs to be more education, training for security guards and staff and managers, to recognise harassment. There isn't enough mention of sexual harassment in security training courses, so we need to influence training curriculum."

"Often the guards are there to protect the venue not the punters. The venues are mostly good citizens, and they want safer spaces. For us, this is about cultural change."

Shannon Driscoll is co-director of the non-profit organisation Girls Rock! Melbourne, which aims to empower young women and gender-diverse people to enter the music industry. She said the group was taking even stronger action to protect minorities in the music scene.

"We try to do a self-defence workshop to teach them about not being afraid to raise their voice or make a scene if someone hurts them. We're also having discussions about the things that might happen to you, talking through the appropriate response, so it sort of normalises their ability to let a bar staff know or let a friend know or tell security, so that's the normal response instead of keeping it bottled up," she told HuffPost Australia.

"It's still very prevalent. There are a lot of great changes being made, venues putting up signs that if you're being harassed or assaulted, to let someone know and the staff will kick them out. We're getting support from venues and the bands on stage who might stop a gig if the crowd is getting violent or acting inappropriately."

Fileborn said venues and festivals still had a way to go before hitting the benchmarks for safety. New innovations like putting signs up in female bathrooms, giving women phone numbers to call or secret codewords to use at the bar to discreetly let staff know if they are being harassed, were good steps forward, but more needed to be done.

A sign at the Courthouse hotel in Newtown, Sydney

"We're seeing some venues looking to take proactive responses, getting involved with the training we're running, starting their own campaigns and putting up signs, while other venues just dont want to know about it or don't see it as their problem," she said.

"There should be a zero tolerance approach to harassment and abuse, plus signs up saying they don't tolerate this behaviour, and if we see you engaging in it, there will be consequences and then following up on that. They need policies in place to support and train staff to know what sexual assault and harassment are, because some of the lower level stuff is not recognised as assault. They must be aware of the full behaviours that constitute sexual harassment and assault."

Fileborn said venues and festivals had made good progress, and looked forward to seeing more done in the future.

"It does seem there's a lot of momentum around the issue. We're starting to see venues and festivals get called out more when harassment and assault occurs, and especially when their response isn't good. It's getting more difficult to ignore."
TITLE: Music Venues, Festivals Must Do More To Stop Sex Abuse At Gigs

A Santa working at a Toronto shopping center dealt with an angry adult rather than an ornery child this past weekend.
A cellphone video posted online shows a woman in a gray and black dress yelling profanities at the Santa on duty at the Dufferin Mall.
‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not magic; you‚Äôre not even real!
‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not real, man.‚ÄùScreenshot c/o Viral Hog This woman was captured on video yelling at a Santa in a Toronto Mall over the weekend.

TEXT:
It‚Äôs definitely Claus for alarm. A Santa working at a Toronto shopping center dealt with an angry adult rather than an ornery child this past weekend. A cellphone video posted online shows a woman in a gray and black dress yelling profanities at the Santa on duty at the Dufferin Mall.

‚ÄúDo you have a sleigh? You fucking dickhead? Do you have a sleigh?‚Äù she can be heard yelling in the video. Calling Santa names is bad enough, but the woman took the next step by declaring that jolly old St. Nick doesn‚Äôt exist. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not magic; you‚Äôre not even real! I heard about it when I was a young kid!‚Äù she yelled. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not real, man.‚Äù

Screenshot c/o Viral Hog This woman was captured on video yelling at a Santa in a Toronto Mall over the weekend.

The person who shot the footage told the video licensing agency Viral Hog that Santa brushed off the abuse and avoided engaging with the woman, who was then questioned by security. A mall spokeswoman confirmed to HuffPost that mall security guards spoke to the woman, who then left without incident. North Pole sources would not confirm or deny that the woman would be getting coal on Dec. 25.
TITLE: Woman Yells At Mall Santa, Tells Him, 'You're Not Even Real!'

SUMMARY:
Prince Harry and Meghan Markle might be hurtling towards a fairytale wedding thanks to a blind date in 2016.
That said, while there are plenty of blind date horror stories floating around, that's not to say they can't end in happiness.
Here, dating pros reveal their dos and don'ts to help you bag yourself a second, not-so-blind date.
Do pick an informal placeChoosing a chilled out setting for your blind date can be very beneficial and can take some of the pressure off, as it allows you to leave if things go terribly.
Do make an effortTania is a firm believer that people should take care over their outfit, the venue and plans when on a blind date.
TEXT:
Prince Harry and Meghan Markle might be hurtling towards a fairytale wedding thanks to a blind date in 2016. But for many, the very idea of being set up by a mate is enough to bring them out in hives.

That said, while there are plenty of blind date horror stories floating around, that's not to say they can't end in happiness. (Or at the very least, amicably.)

Here, dating pros reveal their dos and don'ts to help you bag yourself a second, not-so-blind date.

Do trust your friend

The thought of placing your love life in your best mate's hands might be nerve-racking, but dating coach and expert James Preece said it could actually work wonders for your love life.

"Your friend probably knows you better than you even know yourself," he said. "They'll understand the type of person you need to make you happy rather than the ones you think you want. They've watched you in your previous relationships and have seen you at your best as well as your worst."

Do your research

The benefit of having a friend set you up is that you can get some key intelligence about your date before you meet (without having to trawl through Facebook at the risk of accidentally liking something from 2015).

Tania O'Donnell, author of Slow Dating: A Technophobe's Quest for Love Offline, said: "Ask the person setting you up what the other person is like and if there are any stories they can tell you about him or her. This will provide you with an icebreaker conversation."

Do pick an informal place

Choosing a chilled out setting for your blind date can be very beneficial and can take some of the pressure off, as it allows you to leave if things go terribly.

Tania explained: "Pick an informal place such as a pub or coffee shop and only meet for drinks. If you get along well, you can always extend it to dinner, but if it isn't going well, you're only committed to a couple of drinks and can make the excuse that you have a supper booked with a friend in order to leave."

Dating expert Madeleine Mason, from PassionSmiths, added that first dates should always be a short, 60 to 90-minute "chemistry check" to help you get a feel for whether you'd go on a second date or not.

Do make an effort

Tania is a firm believer that people should take care over their outfit, the venue and plans when on a blind date. After all, if everything goes well you don't want the story of how you met to be clouded by the fact you wore tracksuit bottoms.

"Make an effort with your appearance," she said. "It doesn't come across as desperate or trying too hard - it is a common courtesy to look and smell nice on a special occasion.

"To do less makes it seem as though you're not that bothered and, while some pick-up artists might think this is an appropriate impression to give, it doesn't really bode well for any resulting relationship."
TITLE: 9 Blind Date Survival Tips

SUMMARY:
La parcella di un avvocato barese sar√† pagata da un vecchio cliente insolvente in rate da 10 euro al mese per 23 anni.
Lo ha stabilito il Tribunale di Siena pronunciandosi sulla richiesta di pagamento dell'onorario avanzata dal legale dopo aver difeso per anni un imprenditore senese senza essere stato retribuito.
L'imprenditore, nell'aprile 2014, era stato prosciolto dall'accusa di omesso versamento delle ritenute previdenziali dei dipendenti della ditta barese di cui fino al 2009 era stato legale rappresentante.
Nel marzo del 2015 ad occuparsi della vicenda √® il Tribunale di Siena, competente perch√© l'imprenditore risiede in quella provincia.
Dalle verifiche risulta che l'imprenditore percepisce una pensione mensile di complessivi 630 euro, troppo pochi per ottenere l'intero credito vantato dall'avvocato, il quale da giugno 2015 ha ottenuto il pagamento del suo onorario in rate da 10 euro al mese "fino al soddisfacimento del credito", dice il Tribunale, di quasi 2.800 euro, quindi per pi√π di 23 anni.
TEXT:
La parcella di un avvocato barese sar√† pagata da un vecchio cliente insolvente in rate da 10 euro al mese per 23 anni. Lo ha stabilito il Tribunale di Siena pronunciandosi sulla richiesta di pagamento dell'onorario avanzata dal legale dopo aver difeso per anni un imprenditore senese senza essere stato retribuito.

L'imprenditore, nell'aprile 2014, era stato prosciolto dall'accusa di omesso versamento delle ritenute previdenziali dei dipendenti della ditta barese di cui fino al 2009 era stato legale rappresentante.

Le richieste di pagamento della parcella da parte dell'avvocato erano iniziate a maggio di quello stesso anno, con raccomandante e numerosi successivi solleciti, fino al ricorso per decreto ingiuntivo presentato al Giudice di pace di Bari, esecutivo a dicembre 2014 per l'importo dovuto di 2.793 euro.

Nel marzo del 2015 ad occuparsi della vicenda √® il Tribunale di Siena, competente perch√© l'imprenditore risiede in quella provincia. Su richiesta del legale, i giudici toscani emettono un atto di pignoramento presso l'Inps. Dalle verifiche risulta che l'imprenditore percepisce una pensione mensile di complessivi 630 euro, troppo pochi per ottenere l'intero credito vantato dall'avvocato, il quale da giugno 2015 ha ottenuto il pagamento del suo onorario in rate da 10 euro al mese "fino al soddisfacimento del credito", dice il Tribunale, di quasi 2.800 euro, quindi per pi√π di 23 anni. Con la beffa, per l'avvocato, di aver dovuto pagare un proprio legale di parte per questa controversia, non potendosi difendere da solo, oltre alle spese di registrazione della sentenza pari a circa 200 euro.
TITLE: Parcella legale a rate, il cliente paga 10 euro al mese per 23 anni

√âTATS-UNIS - Donald Trump a affirm√© ce samedi 2 d√©cembre que son ex-conseiller Michael Flynn, inculp√© la veille pour avoir menti au FBI dans l'affaire russe, n'avait rien commis d'ill√©gal pendant la p√©riode de transition, entre la victoire du r√©publicain et son arriv√©e √† la Maison Blanche.

Une r√©action qu'il a, comme d'habitude, publi√©e sur son compte Twitter. Probl√®me, le message du pr√©sident am√©ricain sur le r√©seau social comporte un d√©tail que certains ont imm√©diatement consid√©r√© comme un aveu d'entrave √† la justice.

"J'ai d√ª limoger le g√©n√©ral Flynn parce qu'il a menti au vice-pr√©sident et au FBI. Il a plaid√© coupable de ces mensonges. C'est triste parce que ses actions pendant la transition √©taient l√©gales. Il n'y avait rien √† cacher!".

I had to fire General Flynn because he lied to the Vice President and the FBI. He has pled guilty to those lies. It is a shame because his actions during the transition were lawful. There was nothing to hide!

Donald Trump semble, avec ce message, admettre qu'il savait que son ex-conseiller √† la s√©curit√© nationale avait menti au FBI au moment de le renvoyer le 13 f√©vrier 2017.

Cela pose probl√®me parce qu'√† l'√©poque du d√©part de Michael Flynn, seul le fait qu'il ait menti au vice-pr√©sident Mike Pence sur la teneur de ses √©changes avec l'ambassadeur russe avait √©t√© mis en avant par la Maison Blanche.

Quelques mois plus tard, le 9 mai, Donald Trump d√©cidait de brutalement renvoyer James Comey, le directeur du FBI qui concentrait une partie de son enqu√™te -li√©e aux soup√ßons de collusion avec la Russie- justement sur Michael Flynn.

Dans une audition d√©but juin devant le S√©nat, James Comey avait en alors affirm√© que Donald Trump tentait, avec son renvoi, de faire entrave √† la justice et que le pr√©sident lui avait m√™me personnellement demand√© d'enterrer l'enqu√™te visant Michael Flynn le 14 f√©vrier. Ce que le directeur du FBI avait refus√© de faire.

"J'esp√®re que vous pourrez trouver une fa√ßon d'abandonner cela, de l√¢cher Flynn. C'est un homme bien", aurait dit le pr√©sident √† Comey dans le Bureau ovale, au lendemain du limogeage de Flynn. Trump aurait donc somm√© le FBI d'abandonner une enqu√™te sur l'un de ses proches en sachant que ce m√™me proche √©tait coupable d'avoir menti au FBI.

Sur Twitter, beaucoup n'en ont pas cru leurs yeux en lisant ce message de Trump qui donne donc l'impression que le pr√©sident fournit un d√©tail tr√®s compromettant.

THIS IS OBSTRUCTION OF JUSTICE. @POTUS now admits he KNEW Michael Flynn lied to the FBI. Yet Trump tried to influence or stop the FBI investigation on #Flynn. https://t.co/8JqGBxgou0 ‚Äî Ted Lieu (@tedlieu) December 2, 2017

"C'est de l'entrave √† la justice. Le pr√©sident avoue qu'il savait que Flynn avait menti au FBI et qu'il a tout de m√™me tent√© d'influencer ou d'arr√™ter l'enqu√™te du FBI sur Flynn"

This is a pretty substantial confession to essential knowledge elements of an obstruction of justice charge. https://t.co/UpQfilPVfJ ‚Äî Susan Hennessey (@Susan_Hennessey) December 2, 2017

"C'est une confession assez cons√©quente de connaissance d'√©l√©ments li√©s √† une entrave √† la justice"

Oh my god, he just admitted to obstruction of justice. If Trump knew Flynn lied to the FBI when he asked Comey to let it go, then there is your case. https://t.co/c6Wtd0TfzW ‚Äî Matthew Miller (@matthewamiller) December 2, 2017

"Oh mon dieu, il vient de reconna√Ætre avoir fait entrave √† la justice. Si Trump savait que Flynn avait menti au FBI quand il a demand√© √† Comey d'abandonner son enqu√™te, alors c'est bon l'affaire est boucl√©e"

I'm no lawyer, but a friend of mine who's an excellent attorney says that @realDonaldTrump just admitted to obstruction of justice - and with millions of Americans as witnesses.

üëáüëáüëáhttps://t.co/uYFc4ndGcQ ‚Äî Jon Cooper (@joncoopertweets) December 2, 2017

"Un ami √† moi est un excellent avocat et me dit que Trump vient d'avouer avoir fait entrave √† la justice, devant des millions d'Am√©ricains."
TITLE: Avec ce tweet, Donald Trump a tout l'air d'avoir avou√© par erreur une entrave √† la justice

TEXT:
El pasado 29 de noviembre, Ruby Rose y sus compa√±era de la pel√≠cula Pitch Perfect 3, presentaron en S√≠dney, Australia, el filme que llegar√° a las salas de cine este diciembre.

Pese a la presencia de algunas de las protagonistas como Rebel Wilson, Brittany Snow, Anna Camp y Ruby Rose, esta √∫ltima fue la que acapar√≥ las miradas y todo por su extrema delgadez.

SUMMARY:
Neben Geschenken schaut sich der eine oder andere auch schon nach dem perfekten Baum um.
Neben Geschenken schaut sich der eine oder andere auch schon nach dem perfekten Baum um.
‚ñ∫ Hier gelangt ihr zu TimTanne: Bestellt euren Weihnachtsbaum zum Wunschtermin Der H√§ndler schl√§gt die Weihnachtsb√§ume frisch zum ausgew√§hlten Liefertermin.
Ihr k√∂nnt schon jetzt bestellen und der Baum selbst kommt dann, wann ihr wollt - auch kurz vor Weihnachten Die B√§ume sind regional und nachhaltig angebaut.
Hintergrund: Die wichtigsten Fakten zum WeihnachtsbaumDem Bundesverband der Weihnachtsbaumerzeuger im badischen B√ºhl zufolge ist die Nordmanntanne der beliebteste Weihnachtsbaum.
TEXT:
Der Advent hat begonnen, in knapp vier Wochen ist Weihnachten. Neben Geschenken schaut sich der eine oder andere auch schon nach dem perfekten Baum um. Denn auch wenn es l√§ngst schon wiederverwendbare Plastiktannen gibt - Deutschlands K√§ufer wollen das Original. | AleksandarNakic via Getty Images

Deutschlands Weihnachtsbaumerzeuger betonen: Regionale Tannen und Fichten sind beliebt

Kunden kaufen ihre B√§ume vor allem beim Bauern und an der Stra√üe

Wer eine Nordmanntanne kauft, kann sie sich sp√§ter liefern lassen

Der Advent hat begonnen, in knapp vier Wochen ist Weihnachten. Neben Geschenken schaut sich der eine oder andere auch schon nach dem perfekten Baum um. Denn auch wenn es l√§ngst schon wiederverwendbare Plastiktannen gibt - Deutschlands K√§ufer wollen das Original.

"Wir erleben eine anhaltende Nachfrage nach regionalen B√§umen", sagte Gesch√§ftsf√ºhrer des Bundesverbands der Weihnachtsbaumerzeuger, Martin Rometsch. Der Importanteil der Weihnachtsb√§ume liegt gesch√§tzt nur noch bei zehn Prozent, Hauptherkunftsland ist D√§nemark.

Der Weihnachtsbaum vom Bauern liegt im Trend, noch selten: der Baum aus dem Internet

Au√üerdem ist ein weiterer Trend erkennbar: Gut 30 Prozent der B√§ume werden inzwischen direkt bei den landwirtschaftlichen Betrieben gekauft, sagt Rometsch. Die Kunden wollen B√§ume, die aus ihrer Region stammen.

Vergleichbar viele Tannen und Fichten kommen √ºber den Stra√üenhandel zum Kunden. Der Rest wird in Garten-, Bau- und Superm√§rkten verkauft. Eine Nische besetzt inzwischen aber auch der Onlinehandel.

Dieser bietet, wie manche G√§rtnerei einen Vorteil an: Der Wunschbaum wird direkt nach Hause geliefert. Gerade in Zeiten, in denen nicht jeder ein Auto besitzt, kann das praktisch sein.

Anzeige Nur noch bis zum 17. November: HuffPost-Leser erhalten 10 Prozent auf alle B√§ume

Wer einen Weihnachtsbaum sucht, kann ihn auch im Internet finden. Ein Anbieter f√ºr Nordmanntannen ist TimTanne. ‚ñ∫ Hier gelangt ihr zu TimTanne: Bestellt euren Weihnachtsbaum zum Wunschtermin Der H√§ndler schl√§gt die Weihnachtsb√§ume frisch zum ausgew√§hlten Liefertermin. Ihr k√∂nnt schon jetzt bestellen und der Baum selbst kommt dann, wann ihr wollt - auch kurz vor Weihnachten Die B√§ume sind regional und nachhaltig angebaut. Passend dazu gibt es bei TimTanne auch Lichterketten und Baumst√§nder zu kaufen.

Hintergrund: Die wichtigsten Fakten zum Weihnachtsbaum

Dem Bundesverband der Weihnachtsbaumerzeuger im badischen B√ºhl zufolge ist die Nordmanntanne der beliebteste Weihnachtsbaum. Rund acht von zehn Menschen entscheiden sich f√ºr den Baum mit den weichen Nadeln.

Wer auf den Preis achten m√∂chte, w√§hlt zum Beispiel die Blaufichte. Rotfichten, die fr√ºher der klassische Weihnachtsbaum waren, finden heute nicht mehr viele Liebhaber. Das merkt man auch am Preis. Bis zu Zweidrittel billiger als die Nordmanntanne ist diese Sorte.

Insgesamt d√ºrften in diesem Jahr wieder rund 25 Millionen Weihnachtsb√§ume in Deutschland verkauft werden. Der Absatz ist seit Jahren stabil. Die Zahl beruht nach Angaben des Verbandsgesch√§ftsf√ºhrers Martin Rometsch aber auf Sch√§tzungen.

Weder Landwirtschaftskammern noch Beh√∂rden f√ºhrten Statistiken √ºber Anbaufl√§che und Einschlag. Der Hauptverband der Deutschen Holzindustrie nennt h√∂here Zahlen zum Weihnachtsbaumverkauf.
TITLE: Euren Weihnachtsbaum k√∂nnt ihr auch online kaufen und sp√§ter liefern lassen - Anzeige

SUMMARY:
But it‚Äôs actually the relative non-severity of the charge against Flynn that should have Trump and his top aides worried.
In short, special counsel Robert Mueller‚Äôs team isn‚Äôt done yet.
Now, armed with the cooperation of Flynn and Papadopoulos and with significant leverage against Manafort and Gates, Mueller‚Äôs team appears poised for another takedown.
First, there‚Äôs a ‚Äúsenior official‚Äù on the Trump transition team who was at Trump‚Äôs Mar-a-Lago resort on Dec. 29.
McFarland, a former top administration official Trump has nominated to become an ambassador, was the ‚Äúsenior official‚Äù in question.
TEXT:
WASHINGTON ‚Äï Former national security adviser Michael Flynn, the man President Donald Trump trusted with the nation‚Äôs closest-held secrets, is now a felon, admitting in federal court Friday that he lied to FBI agents just days after his former boss was sworn in as president. But it‚Äôs actually the relative non-severity of the charge against Flynn that should have Trump and his top aides worried.

Flynn, who served as Trump‚Äôs national security adviser for 24 days before he was fired for reportedly lying to Vice President Mike Pence about the content of his discussions with the Russian ambassador weeks before Trump‚Äôs inauguration, had significant legal exposure. As did his son Michael Flynn Jr. So the fact that he struck a plea deal with just a single count that could potentially mean no prison time indicates he‚Äôs been able to leverage significant information on an even bigger target. In short, special counsel Robert Mueller‚Äôs team isn‚Äôt done yet.

‚ÄúUsually in government investigations they don‚Äôt cooperate down, they cooperate up,‚Äù Mark Lee, a former federal prosecutor, told HuffPost. ‚ÄúGen. Flynn is probably a medium-sized fish. They‚Äôre looking for a bigger fish than him.‚Äù

Jonathan Ernst / Reuters Former national security adviser Michael Flynn leaves U.S. District Court in Washington on Friday morning. It looks like a bigger shoe could soon drop.

Trump has dismissed Mueller‚Äôs probe as a ‚Äúwitch hunt‚Äù and a ‚Äúhoax,‚Äù and the White House is already trying to distance the administration from Flynn. But the investigation has already resulted in two guilty pleas ‚Äï from Flynn and former Trump campaign adviser George Papadopoulos ‚Äï as well as hefty criminal charges against Trump‚Äôs former campaign manager Paul Manafort and his deputy Rick Gates. Now, armed with the cooperation of Flynn and Papadopoulos and with significant leverage against Manafort and Gates, Mueller‚Äôs team appears poised for another takedown.

‚ÄúFlynn would not be permitted to enter a plea bargain unless he had substantial credible evidence of criminal activity involving high-level members of the Trump campaign, including potentially the president himself,‚Äù Notre Dame Law School professor Jimmy Gurul√© said. ‚ÄúClearly this is not good news for President Trump.‚Äù

Two individuals specifically referenced in court documents in connection with Flynn‚Äôs guilty plea Friday should be particularly nervous.

First, there‚Äôs a ‚Äúsenior official‚Äù on the Trump transition team who was at Trump‚Äôs Mar-a-Lago resort on Dec. 29. According to his statement of offense, Flynn made a call that day to ‚Äúa senior official‚Äù who was ‚Äúwith other senior members‚Äù of the transition team at Mar-a-Lago. This was the day after the Obama administration had announced sanctions against Russia in response to Russia‚Äôs interference in the 2016 election and Russian ambassador Sergey Kislyak had contacted Flynn for a chat.

In that Dec. 29 call, Flynn and other members of the Trump transition team, according to the statement of offense, ‚Äúdiscussed the U.S. Sanctions, including the potential impact of those sanctions on the incoming administration‚Äôs foreign policy goals.‚Äù Then, ‚Äúimmediately‚Äù after talking to the official, Flynn called the Russian ambassador and asked that Russia not escalate the situation. Fox News, CNN and ABC reported Friday that K.T. McFarland, a former top administration official Trump has nominated to become an ambassador, was the ‚Äúsenior official‚Äù in question.

Mark Wilson via Getty Images

Second, there‚Äôs the ‚Äúvery senior member of the Presidential Transition Team‚Äù who, on Dec. 22, directed Flynn to call other countries, including Russia, to learn where governments stood on a U.N. Security Council resolution on Israeli settlements. Multiple outlets have reported that this is Jared Kushner, Trump‚Äôs son-in-law and adviser. Flynn, according to his statement of offense, requested that Russia either vote against or delay the resolution. Flynn admitted he lied when he told FBI agents that he asked only for their position on the vote and didn‚Äôt request they take any particular action.

Flynn‚Äôs admissions that he acted on behalf of the Trump transition team to interfere with U.S. foreign policy raises the potential of charges under the Logan Act, a never-used 1799 statute than bans citizens from interfering in foreign relations, as well as potential other criminal statutes.

As part of his plea deal, Flynn has agreed to ‚Äúcooperate fully, truthfully, completely, and forthrightly‚Äù with Mueller‚Äôs office or any other federal, state and local law enforcement authorities Mueller‚Äôs office identifies where Flynn‚Äôs cooperation would be relevant. Flynn also must ‚Äúpromptly‚Äù turn over ‚Äúany and all evidence of crimes‚Äù of which he‚Äôs aware.
TITLE: Mike Flynn Wasn't Robert Mueller's 'Big Fish.' Why The Trump Team Should Be Worried.

TEXT:
HARC√àLEMENT - "Suiscide toi", "On vas te faire la mis√®re", "√† se soire √† la sortie"... Le 28 novembre 2017, une lyc√©enne vosgienne publient les lettres d'insultes adress√©es √† sa ni√®ce, scolaris√©e en sixi√®me. Les menaces, d'une violence inou√Øe, scandalisent les r√©seaux sociaux, et plusieurs m√©dias, dont Le HuffPost relaient l'histoire.

En quelques jours, le tweet d'Oph√©lie Dodeman, la tante de la victime pr√©sum√©e est partag√© pr√®s de 30.000 fois et attire l'attention d'internautes influents. Le chroniqueur Jeremstar publie, notamment, un message d'indignation, les parents portent plainte et l'administration du coll√®ge cherche les responsables. Oph√©lie Dodeman explique avoir re√ßu plus de "200 lettres de soutien destin√©es √† [sa] ni√®ce."

Il faudrait que toi et @jeremstar (2 PERSONNALIT√âS QUI PRENNENT CE PROBL√àME A COEUR) obtient un Rdv avec @jmblanquer ce fl√©au devient monnaie courante m√™me s'il y a des directives il y a toujours ce probl√®me non r√©solu la preuve vu ces injures ( via @OphelieDodeman) üëáüëáüëá pic.twitter.com/80bS5pkGRU 30 novembre 2017 Je suis scandalis√© et tellement en col√®re. Qui est cette petite? D'o√π viennent ces lettres? C'est d'une violence inou√Øe https://t.co/HFJwNB6A5r 29 novembre 2017

Seulement, samedi 2 d√©cembre, soit quelques jours apr√®s la publication des lettres, Vosges Matin explique que la jeune coll√©gienne a tout invent√© et qu'elle n'est pas victime de harc√®lement. "L'enqu√™te des policiers d'Epinal a r√©v√©l√© qu'il s'agissait en fait d'un appel au secours de l'adolescente. Elle voulait juste qu'on s'int√©resse √† elle", explique le site d'informations locales.

Apr√®s ce rebondissement, les tweets de la tante de la fausse victime ont √©t√© rapidement supprim√©s, avant que son compte ne disparaisse compl√®tement.
TITLE: Harc√®lement scolaire: la coll√©gienne menac√©e, dont la tante avait publi√© les lettres, a tout invent√©

SUMMARY:
Trump sort les √âtats-Unis d'un pacte sur les migrants et continue de d√©truire le bilan d'Obama.
Ce Pacte doit reposer sur deux axes: d√©finition d'un cadre des r√©ponses √† apporter √† la probl√©matique et programme d'actions.
"En cons√©quence, le pr√©sident Trump a d√©cid√© l'arr√™t de la participation des √âtats-Unis √† la pr√©paration du Pacte qui vise √† obtenir un consensus √† l'ONU en 2018", a-t-elle ajout√©.
"Et le multilat√©ralisme reste le meilleur moyen pour faire face √† des d√©fis mondiaux", a-t-il ajout√©, cit√© par son porte-parole, Brenden Varma.
Le retrait am√©ricain du projet de Pacte mondial sur les migrations intervient alors que le Conseil de s√©curit√© de l'ONU a multipli√© en novembre les r√©unions sur la question migratoire.
TEXT:
Trump sort les √âtats-Unis d'un pacte sur les migrants et continue de d√©truire le bilan d'Obama.

INTERNATIONAL - Les √âtats-Unis ont ajout√© le 2 d√©cembre un nouveau secteur, celui des migrants et r√©fugi√©s, √† une longue liste de projets ou d'accords internationaux dont Donald Trump a d√©cid√© de retirer son pays au grand dam des partisans du multilat√©ralisme.

"La mission am√©ricaine aupr√®s de l'ONU a inform√© son secr√©taire g√©n√©ral que les √âtats-Unis mettaient fin √† leur participation au Pacte mondial sur la migration", a annonc√© dans un communiqu√© l'administration am√©ricaine.

Un pacte mondial devait √™tre sign√© en 2018

En septembre 2016, les 193 membres de l'Assembl√©e g√©n√©rale de l'ONU avaient adopt√© √† l'unanimit√© un texte appel√© D√©claration de New York pour les r√©fugi√©s et les migrants qui vise √† am√©liorer √† l'avenir leur gestion internationale (accueil, aide aux retours...).

Sur la base de cette D√©claration, le Haut commissaire aux R√©fugi√©s a √©t√© mandat√© pour proposer un Pacte mondial sur les migrants et r√©fugi√©s dans son rapport annuel √† l'Assembl√©e g√©n√©rale en 2018. Ce Pacte doit reposer sur deux axes: d√©finition d'un cadre des r√©ponses √† apporter √† la probl√©matique et programme d'actions.

"La D√©claration de New York comprend plusieurs dispositions qui sont incompatibles avec les politiques am√©ricaines d'immigration et de r√©fugi√©s et les principes √©dict√©s par l'Administration Trump en mati√®re d'immigration", a expliqu√© dans un communiqu√© la mission des √âtats-Unis aupr√®s de l'ONU, sans dire lesquelles. "En cons√©quence, le pr√©sident Trump a d√©cid√© l'arr√™t de la participation des √âtats-Unis √† la pr√©paration du Pacte qui vise √† obtenir un consensus √† l'ONU en 2018", a-t-elle ajout√©.

"Incompatible avec la souverainet√© am√©ricaine"

Depuis son entr√©e en fonction en janvier, le r√©publicain Donald Trump a entrepris de prendre le contre-pied de nombre d'engagements pris par son pr√©d√©cesseur d√©mocrate Barack Obama. Plusieurs mesures ont d√©j√† vis√© le secteur de l'immigration aux √âtats-Unis.

"L'Am√©rique est fi√®re de son h√©ritage en mati√®re d'immigration et de son leadership dans le soutien aux populations migrantes et r√©fugi√©es √† travers le monde", a soulign√© dans le communiqu√© l'ambassadrice am√©ricaine √† l'ONU, Nikki Haley. Mais "l'approche mondiale de la D√©claration de New York est juste incompatible avec la souverainet√© am√©ricaine", a-t-elle expliqu√©.

"Nos d√©cisions sur les politiques d'immigration doivent toujours √™tre prises par les Am√©ricains et les seuls Am√©ricains", a insist√© Nikki Haley, qui a le rang de ministre aux √âtats-Unis et qui est une fid√®le du pr√©sident am√©ricain.

Les √âtats-Unis isol√©s sur le climat

"Les migrations sont un probl√®me mondial qui r√©clame une r√©ponse mondiale", a r√©torqu√© dans un communiqu√© le pr√©sident en exercice de l'Assembl√©e g√©n√©rale de l'ONU, le chef de la diplomatie slovaque, Miroslav Lajcak, en d√©plorant la d√©cision am√©ricaine. "Et le multilat√©ralisme reste le meilleur moyen pour faire face √† des d√©fis mondiaux", a-t-il ajout√©, cit√© par son porte-parole, Brenden Varma.

La premi√®re ann√©e de pr√©sidence de Donald Trump a √©t√© marqu√©e par plusieurs retraits spectaculaires d'accords internationaux ou de projets d'accords impliquant plusieurs pays du monde. Au risque de l'isolement, les √âtats-Unis, premi√®re puissance mondiale, sont devenus le seul pays √† ne plus vouloir faire partie de l'Accord de Paris (2015) visant √† limiter le r√©chauffement climatique de la plan√®te.

Rohingya et esclaves en Libye

Washington a aussi d√©cid√© r√©cemment de se retirer de l'Unesco, l'Organisation des Nations Unies pour l'Education, la Science et la Culture, que Donald Trump juge peu favorable √† Isra√´l. Dans un autre domaine, la lutte contre la prolif√©ration nucl√©aire, le pr√©sident am√©ricain ne reconnait plus que l'Iran respecte un accord international de 2015 visant √† garantir le caract√®re pacifique de son programme atomique. Cette position est un premier pas vers une possible fin pour cet accord.

Le retrait am√©ricain du projet de Pacte mondial sur les migrations intervient alors que le Conseil de s√©curit√© de l'ONU a multipli√© en novembre les r√©unions sur la question migratoire. Apr√®s la crise des migrants et r√©fugi√©s cherchant √† gagner l'Europe, le sujet a repris de l'acuit√© avec l'exode massive depuis ao√ªt de Rohingya de Birmanie vers le Bangladesh et des informations sur l'existence de march√©s d'esclaves en Libye.

√Ä voir √©galement sur Le HuffPost:
TITLE: Trump sort les √âtats-Unis d'un pacte sur les migrants et continue de d√©truire le bilan d'Obama

SUMMARY:
Former South African Airways (SAA) chairperson Dudu Myeni has been appointed as special adviser to Transport Minister Joe Maswanganyi, Timeslive reported on Sunday.
This takes place as government considers moving SAA from National Treasury to the Department of Transport.
However, South Africa's top banks warned that it could recall roughly R8 billion that SAA owes to them.
The Finance Minister's spokesperson Mayihlome Tshwete has told the Sunday Times that the department is not aware of any plans to move SAA.
However, the Transport Minister has confirmed that a national review to move the airline to his department was underway.
TEXT:
Former South African Airways (SAA) chairperson Dudu Myeni has been appointed as special adviser to Transport Minister Joe Maswanganyi, Timeslive reported on Sunday.

The controversial appointment could see Myeni take home around R1-million a year.

This takes place as government considers moving SAA from National Treasury to the Department of Transport.

However, South Africa's top banks warned that it could recall roughly R8 billion that SAA owes to them.

The Finance Minister's spokesperson Mayihlome Tshwete has told the Sunday Times that the department is not aware of any plans to move SAA.

However, the Transport Minister has confirmed that a national review to move the airline to his department was underway.
TITLE: Former SAA Boss Dudu Myeni Lands New Top Job

SUMMARY:
When John Quinn was diagnosed with dementia at 52 it took him a good couple of years to come to terms with it.
John is amongst over 400,000 Australians currently living with dementia, and almost 26,000 with younger onset dementia.
"It would in principle mean that dementia could be cured," Professor Jurgen Gotz, Director of Queensland Brain Institutes Clem Jones Centre for Ageing Dementia Research, tells HuffPost Australia.
John QuinnDespite seeing his own mother pass away from dementia, John has an incredibly positive attitude towards the disease.
Professor J√ºrgen G√∂tz has lead research at QBI into non-invasive ultrasound technology that hold promise for dementia patients.
TEXT:
When John Quinn was diagnosed with dementia at 52 it took him a good couple of years to come to terms with it.

Not only was his grappling with his sense of identity, but he had to figure out how he was going to get on with life and enjoy it, despite the dementia.

"As much as I think you need to portray the dark side of dementia, it also has two phases, he tells HuffPost Australia.

SUBSCRIBE AND FOLLOW Get top stories and blog posts emailed to me each day. Newsletters may offer personalized content or advertisements. Learn more Newsletter Please enter a valid email address Thank you for signing up! You should receive an email to confirm your subscription shortly. There was a problem processing your signup; please try again later Facebook

YouTube

Snapchat

Instagram

CLOSE

"And the other phase is there is this misconception when you get a diagnosis of dementia it means end of life and with many of us, particularly those of us diagnosed young, it doesn't mean that at all. It just simply means some of the abilities and things we could do previously we can no longer do."

John is amongst over 400,000 Australians currently living with dementia, and almost 26,000 with younger onset dementia.

But over the last two years, scientists at the University of Queensland within the Queensland Brain Institute (QBI) have been developing ultrasound technology that holds hope for patients like John.

Using non-invasive ultrasound technology, the team at QBI discovered they could break apart amyloid plaque and tau proteins that develop within the brain of those with dementia, causing memory loss and cognitive decline.

"It would in principle mean that dementia could be cured," Professor Jurgen Gotz, Director of Queensland Brain Institutes Clem Jones Centre for Ageing Dementia Research, tells HuffPost Australia.

John Quinn

Despite seeing his own mother pass away from dementia, John has an incredibly positive attitude towards the disease.

Since his diagnosis six years ago he has travelled the world, completing the Great Wall of China half marathon in 2013, he's walked the Larapinta Trail in the Northern Territory, as well as the Camino de Santiago in 2011. He also speaks at conferences across the globe and around Australia.

John has learnt Spanish as a second language, completes crossword puzzles with his non-dominant hand and writes regular letters to the editor of The Courier Mail on social issues, politics and education.

A former school principal, John naturally created an acronym for himself to use each day to help him cope with and treat his dementia.

"NAMES: nutrition, acceptance and attitude, mental activities and mindfulness, exercise, social engagement and sleep," John said.

"Everyday I think about my NAMES. It keeps me on track. And because my symptoms are evolving I have to have them uppermost in my mind. I have daily challenges and don't always do my best. But I try my best to get up and get out and do things. No use in moping."

Professor J√ºrgen G√∂tz has lead research at QBI into non-invasive ultrasound technology that hold promise for dementia patients.

Since this technology was discovered by QBI in 2015, they have conducted trials in the brains of mice to the thicker skulls of sheep and are now hoping to translate this research from animals into humans, within the next three to five years.

But Gotz says the discovery that ultrasound can safely open the blood brain barrier is a significant finding in itself.

"There's an estimate that only 2 percent of drugs, which have been developed for brain diseases, actually make it into the brain, Gotz tells HuffPost Australia.

"So by having a device which would open the blood brain barrier safely would now have a means to open the blood brain barrier for 98 percent of drugs which have been developed for brain diseases, which in principle would do the job but have simply been prevented from entering the brain."

If you would like to donate to furthering this research, visit The University of Queensland's page.
TITLE: Watch: Australia's Dementia Medical Breakthrough

SUMMARY:
Le 23 novembre, Gilles Simeoni qualifiait encore de "peur fantasmatique" l'id√©e d'un "processus d'ind√©pendance qui, par contagion, pourrait s'√©tendre de la Catalogne √† la Corse, voire √† des r√©gions hexagonales".
"La Corse n'est pas la Catalogne", martelait-il dans une tribune publi√©e dans Le Monde.
Mais les Corses savent bien que la r√©alit√© √©conomique et politique de la Catalogne n'est pas la leur.
La Catalogne et la Corse (330.000 habitants en 2016, 0,4% du PIB national), c'est "le g√©ant et le nain", ironise Gilles Simeoni.
Un r√©f√©rendum sur un vrai changement statutaire en Corse ne pourrait √™tre organis√© qu'en accord avec l'√âtat".
TEXT:
IND√âPENDANCE - Deux ans seulement apr√®s les r√©gionales de d√©cembre 2015, les √©lecteurs corses sont de nouveau appel√©s aux urnes. Ces 3 et 10 d√©cembre, ils doivent √©lire les 63 membres de la nouvelle Collectivit√© territoriale unique de Corse (CTU), fusion des deux d√©partements actuels et de l'ancienne collectivit√© territoriale (r√©gion). Une instance in√©dite en France m√©tropolitaine, qui verra le jour le 1er janvier 2018.

En 2015, les √©lections avaient d√©bouch√© sur la victoire historique de la coalition nationaliste des autonomistes et des ind√©pendantistes (35,34% au second tour). Cette coalition, form√©e d√®s le premier tour cette ann√©e, appara√Æt √† nouveau bien plac√©e pour l'emporter dans les urnes. Et, deux mois seulement apr√®s la tenue d'un r√©f√©rendum d'ind√©pendance en Catalogne, leur position confortable r√©veille les interrogations sur leurs aspirations ind√©pendantistes.

Car malgr√© l'√©chec de la d√©marche catalane et la mise sous tutelle de la r√©gion par Madrid, l'action de Carles Puigdemont, figure du combat pour l'ind√©pendance de la r√©gion, a √©t√© accueillie favorablement et salu√©e avec respect par une partie de la classe politique en Corse. Peu avant le r√©f√©rendum, les nationalistes (majoritaires) de l'Assembl√©e ont fait adopter une motion soulignant "la l√©gitimit√© incontestable du gouvernement de la Catalogne".

Le pr√©sident sortant de l'Assembl√©e de Corse Jean-Guy Talamoni et celui du conseil ex√©cutif Gilles Simeoni, t√™tes de proue de la coalition nationaliste, ont r√©guli√®rement apport√© leur soutien au "peuple libre" de la Catalogne.

Combat perdu d'avance pour une Espagne d√©rivant vers l'autoritarisme. On n'arr√™te pas un peuple libre #independencia #1OvotaremSI ‚Äî Jean-Guy Talamoni (@JeanGuyTalamoni) 20 septembre 2017

Minist√®res perquisitionn√©s, fonctionnaires arr√™t√©s, mat√©riel √©lectoral saisi: soutien total aux peuple, maires et Gouvernement de #Catalunya https://t.co/C2waPD3qUi ‚Äî Gilles Simeoni (@Gilles_Simeoni) 20 septembre 2017

Les "amis" catalans

La d√©marche d'une minorit√© nationale, unie derri√®re un drapeau, une langue et une culture, cherchant √† s'√©manciper d'un pouvoir central auquel elle se consid√®re assujettie, a forc√©ment fait √©cho sur l'√Æle, o√π trois des quatre d√©put√©s √©lus en juin sont issus de P√® a Corsica, la coalition nationaliste men√©e par Gilles Simeoni. Ce dernier avait d'ailleurs rencontr√© en avril 2016 Carles Puigdemont, pr√©sident destitu√© de la G√©n√©ralit√© de Catalogne. Le jour du vote pour l'ind√©pendance, des repr√©sentants du mouvement nationaliste corse ont m√™me fait le d√©placement √† Barcelone.

Six jours avant le vote catalan, le FLNC dit "du 22 octobre", mouvement clandestin corse qui a annonc√© en mai 2016 la "cessation" de ses actions arm√©es, a √©galement pris part au d√©bat. Dans un registre offensif, qui n'est pas celui de la coalition politique nationaliste, le groupe a menac√© de "provoquer par le vote un √©lan populaire" similaire √† celui de la Catalogne, "si l'√âtat fran√ßais" n'acceptait pas "de s'engager dans un processus de r√©vision constitutionnelle" pour donner √† la Corse un "statut politique √©mancipateur".

Mais, si Jean-Guy Talamoni justifie ce soutien envers ses "amis" de longue date de Catalogne, qui "souhaitent pouvoir s'exprimer d√©mocratiquement", il reconna√Æt que la Corse n'en est "pas du tout au stade de provoquer un r√©f√©rendum". "Nous sommes aujourd'hui ce qu'√©tait la Catalogne avant 2006 et l'accord sur un statut d'autonomie √©largie (dont une partie-cl√© a √©t√© annul√©e en 2010, ndlr)", explique-t-il au HuffPost. "Quand la Corse aura un statut √©conomique et politique plus large, je suis persuad√© que les Corses choisiront l'ind√©pendance. Et je verrai d'un mauvais ≈ìil que Paris s'y oppose", ajoute-t-il.

Le 23 novembre, Gilles Simeoni qualifiait encore de "peur fantasmatique" l'id√©e d'un "processus d'ind√©pendance qui, par contagion, pourrait s'√©tendre de la Catalogne √† la Corse, voire √† des r√©gions hexagonales". "La Corse n'est pas la Catalogne", martelait-il dans une tribune publi√©e dans Le Monde.

Ma Tribune dans Le Monde.

Quand une Constitution ne permet pas de reconna√Ætre un peuple, il faut changer la Constitution, et non pas demander au peuple de dispara√Ætre.

Le 3 d√©cembre disons-le, tous ensemble, par notre vote ! #UnPaeseDaF√† pic.twitter.com/SvwmiP5weo ‚Äî Gilles Simeoni (@Gilles_Simeoni) 23 novembre 2017

"L'id√©e d'un r√©f√©rendum en Corse est ancienne, explique Andr√© Fazi, politologue et ma√Ætre de conf√©rences en sciences politiques √† l'Universit√© de Corse. Mais les Corses savent bien que la r√©alit√© √©conomique et politique de la Catalogne n'est pas la leur. Il y a √† Barcelone une culture √©tatique tr√®s forte, ainsi qu'un personnel politique et administratif dont les Corses ne disposent pas."

La Catalogne et la Corse, "le g√©ant et le nain"

C'est d'ailleurs cette diff√©rence de poids qui a pouss√© les Catalans √† passer en force avec ce r√©f√©rendum, pourtant contraire aux lois du pays. Car la Catalogne, avec ses 7,5 millions d'habitants, est tout simplement la r√©gion la plus riche d'Espagne, au coude-√†-coude avec Madrid: elle repr√©sentait en 2016 19% du PIB espagnol, est un grand acteur industriel, de tr√®s loin la premi√®re r√©gion exportatrice d'Espagne, et la premi√®re r√©gion touristique du pays. La Catalogne et la Corse (330.000 habitants en 2016, 0,4% du PIB national), c'est "le g√©ant et le nain", ironise Gilles Simeoni.

Comme en Espagne, les vell√©it√©s ind√©pendantistes corses se heurteraient aux limites de la Constitution, qui ont invalid√© le scrutin catalan. Comme l'explique Le Monde, la Constitution espagnole reconna√Æt en effet le "droit √† l'autonomie des r√©gions" mais interdit le droit √† l'ind√©pendance au nom de "l'unit√© indissoluble de la nation espagnole".

En France, la Constitution limite √©galement l'organisation des r√©f√©rendums r√©gionaux et locaux aux questions "relevant de la comp√©tence de la collectivit√© qui l'organise". Le gouvernement garde la main sur les questions relatives √† la souverainet√© nationale. "Les r√©f√©rendums locaux sont √©troitement encadr√©s par l'√âtat, confirme Andr√© Fazi. Un r√©f√©rendum sur un vrai changement statutaire en Corse ne pourrait √™tre organis√© qu'en accord avec l'√âtat".

L'√©lection de la CTU, une √©ch√©ance primordiale

Si un r√©f√©rendum d'ind√©pendance en Corse n'est pas √† l'ordre du jour, les nationalistes se pr√©parent toutefois avec beaucoup d'attention √† l'√©ch√©ance de ce dimanche. Car les mouvements autonomiste (de Gilles Simeoni) et ind√©pendantiste (de Jean-Guy Talamoni), unis, ont un objectif principal: "obtenir dans les trois ans un statut d'autonomie" et "le mettre en ≈ìuvre en dix ans".

"L'autonomie de la Corse est un point d'√©quilibre, c'est l'option institutionnelle qui nous convient le mieux", explique Gilles Simeoni, interrog√© par Le HuffPost. L'accord pr√©voit notamment le transfert "progressif" du "pouvoir l√©gislatif dans les domaines non r√©galiens", de la comp√©tence fiscale (pr√©l√®vement de la TVA, de l'imp√¥t sur le revenu...), du pouvoir administratif, ou la reconnaissance de la coofficialit√© de la langue corse.

Ce scrutin pourrait leur ouvrir une voie de dialogue importante avec Paris. "S'ils devaient obtenir une majorit√© absolue √† l'Assembl√©e de Corse, rejeter fermement toutes leurs demandes comporterait des risques pour le pouvoir central, pr√©dit Andr√© Fazi. Ce serait une position propre √† renforcer l'ind√©pendantisme".

A voir √©galement sur Le HuffPost:
TITLE: Apr√®s l'√©lection de la Collectivit√© territoriale unique en Corse, un sc√©nario √† la catalane est-il possible?
